The flavor starts sweet and malty with obvious spicy Belgian yeast and flows into a wonderful fruitiness with lovely hints of sour, almost like the best Smarties youve ever had.  The mouthfeel is hugely carbonated, but with nice small and soft carbonation.  Delish!
UPDATED: APR 17, 2013 33cl bottle sample at the klooster.  Excellent bier!  Nice white head.  Lovely taste. Very dark beer

Thanks to HenrikS and DØE: Dark brown, almost black. Sediments. Has an off-white head, mostly diminishing. Lot of aroma, dark bread, dark fruit, laqurice, plum, resins, port. Flavor is heavy sweet, finish moderate bitter. Creamy texture.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2010 Pannepot of 2008
Aroma: strong roasted coffee with hazlenuts
Full coffee flavour with hints of chocolate and a light aftertaste of caramel.
Pannepot of 2004 (first Pannepot)
Very sweet coffee smell and taste with hints of amaretto.

Courtesy of jtclockwork.  07 bottle.  Very dark pour with a thick frothy tan head on top.  A thick foam stays on top until the last drop.  The aroma shows plenty of spices and funk with yeast, champagne notes, sour apples and dark cherries.  Nice.  Flavors are slightly tart; apples, pears, ripe dark fruit.  Lots of candi sugar and yeasty notes as well.  Theres a taste in there Im having trouble putting my finger on.  Like wet wood or cardboard but it could be just the funky yeast on the backend.  Slick and all too drinkable for 10%.  Really good stuff.

Appearence - body is dark brown/laquered wood colour, small tan head fades quickly. Aroma - complex, full nose, bready, sugary, with port, wood, dates & figs, hint of bitter chocolate, presence of piney hops. Palate/Flavour - soft foamy meduim-full but light body, rich flavours of dark fruits, port, burnt caramel/toffee, spices, with a dark fruit/vinous finish. Overall - delicious, well deserving of its reputation

Bottle. Thanks tarheels! This beer is just amazing. Pours brown/amber a gigantic ice cream tan tan head. Flavor is sweet with chocolate, caramel, espresso, and God knows how many other spices. Delicious.

Easily one of the best beers I have ever had. Was expecting something like an apt/quad, and i guess it was in a way, but this was so easy to drink. Usually with a beer like this, the abv or the ingrediants make me take my time and although im having a beer that i know is fantastic, the flavors are sometimes too much for me and it starts to become a chore after awhile, but this was just absolutely delicious all the way through. Hearty, yes...but also lean and crisp. almost an extra stout feel to it, roasted malts with a wonderful hop balance. really extraordinary

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 2006. dark plum and pepper, some blackberry and honey. Dark coffee brown. Licorice, toffee, espresso, burnt caramel, prunes and beauty.  200312  Another 2006 bottle, seemed to like it a bit more than before.  Firm spice character.

Bottle at Beer Bistro in Toronto 03/10. Intense rich malty aroma with hints of dried fruit and vanilla and cinnamon. Dark dark brown with frothy head. Bottle frothed over when opened. Thick cream syrup mouthfeel is immediately evident. Sweet caramel and malt flavours balanced by bitter chocolate, vanilla, and spices. Light woodiness, caramel, cloves, brown sugar and licorice. An intense mouthfeel, well carbonated and rich with a long duration and slightly alcoholic finish. Almost explodes on the palate. Very satisfying. Excellent overall.
A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. just a little hot and boring. it tastes true to style, just not my cup of tea.

2008 bottle. Brown-red, a bit murky. Sweet dry fruits with lots of spices. Its like a liquid spicy fruitcake with caramel sauce on it, plus some alcohol, and thats very nice indeed. Oh, there are some coffeeish notes too, in the background though. Creamy, almost sticky, mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours deep deep brown with a tan head. The aroma is malty and yeasty with notes of dark fruits, toast, caramel, and spices. Big Belgian yeasty flavor, with some dark fruits and spices. A bit more carbonated than I would have liked. Really good.

Wheeeeee dogs! Big beer! Poured with a huge, light tan, fine, foamy, thick head and some lace. Color is lightly cloudy, reddish brown. Aroma is malt, toffee, dark ripe fruit, leather, dark earth, and licorice. Flavor is like nose but with big sweet and some bitter. Body is excellent with perfect carbonation for this particular beer. Finish is like flavor plus alcohol warmth and is fairly long. Nice end of the day brew.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2007 vintage

A: Rich ruby accented brown body... massive pinkish-tan head... good retention and light lacing.

S: Deep, dark fruits... raisins, cherries, currants, figs.. some caramel and chocolate... light booze burning through.

T: Much like the nose, there is a lot of rich dark fruits here... slight tartness towards the end... booze is noticeable but restrained... nice chocolate/caramel malt base

M: Assertive carbonation, clean finish... medium bodied...

O: A very nice quad that is a proven treat.

11.2oz bottle, 2007. Pours a rich brown-black with a vigorous light brown head and light lacing. Aroma is bready, rich, and vinous, with raisins, spice, and a little booze. Flavor is rich with honey-like sweetness, along with more spices, plum, liquorice, cane sugar. Smooth, even with fairly high carbonation. Very tasty, no doubt about it. In a way it reminds me of some of the great sweet meads Ive had, like Apis Poltorak Jadwiga - sweet, boozy, and spicy, all in a beautiful expressive blend. Id love to have this available locally - Im sure itd be a frequent treat.

Bottle. The aroma is very malty, light sweet and alcoholic. The head is small, beige and creamy with a normal duration, the body is nearly black. The taste is very malty, light bitter and a little bit sweet, a little bit like syrup. The body is medium strong to very strong with a texture like syrup, creamy and light  oily with a normal carbonation.
fruity, spiced, licorice, raisin really complex aromas. strong and perfectly equilibrated taste. amazing body and texture.

Unknown to me till recently (Canvas). I Find this to be one of the best on the planet.  Taste varies slightly for brew to brew, but that is probably to be expected anyway (and the case for all others as well).
This has the richest taste (and the variations of reserva and grand reserva as well) of everything I came across.  Hats off to the Struise-Boys.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2013 Det första ser är en fin och mycket mörk mahogneyfärg. Skummet var inget att prata om.

Doften är fantastisk komplex, och även om detta inte är en dedikerat julöl, så är faktisk jul det första jag tänker på när jag sätter nosen ned i glaset. Det doftar härliga kryddor, malt, julmust och en hel del mynta. Tycker även jag känner en liten aning tobak.

Smaken är mycket söt, och som i doften är det mycket av allt. Kryddor, mynta, lite tobak och även mörka teblad.
Även om båda doft och smak är mycket av allt, så tycker jag att ölen känns ganska rund i munhålen. Den känns inte alls jobbig på något sätt  jag bara njuter.
Alkoholprocenten ger ölen en perfekt balanserad hetta.

i think this beer is the best among all of the belgians.
better than any of the trappists, including westvleteren 12 and rochefort 10.
of course, theyre all good.
i just think this one is the best.  has the most going on / is the most interesting and most enjoyable.

Bottle 2006 .An opaque dark reddish brown pour with a huge beige head that left some spotty lacing and hung around awhile. Aroma is of sweet dark fruit, cherries, sweet malt, apple, chocolate and booze. Flavor is a pretty complex mix of dark fruit, wood, spice,coco, and alcohol. Mouthfeel is rich and full and finishes, with a lingering oakiness, slightly sour on end . Full body , lively carbonation. I thought it was good but not over the top .

Aroma:Mild spicy aroma, raisins and rum.

Appearance:Cloudy, weak lacing

Taste:Dark raisins, spices, fruity. Hot alcohol as it warms. Cherries.

Palate:Hot warmth, thick viscosity. Creaminess.

Overall:Excellent, surprisingly fruity. Should have been more clear

Bottle, 2007 vintage. Deep opaque brown pour with a fgood looking frothy beige head. No head after 5 sec. The vinous aroma has a really nice touch of yeast sweetness with a flowery touch. Nice berries and caramel from the malts. Hints of cheeries, raisins and dried dark fruits. Taste is dominated by the yeast as well but has more of a malt side. Slightly roasted, hints of coffee, burnt caramel, cinnamon, figs, dates, hints of sweet liqourice. Very high carbonation, maybe a bit too much. But a very good brew, a fine balance between the often dominating yeast and the roasted malts and spices.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2011 Nuts, sugarcane. Sticky sweetness in taste, yet not in aroma. Some hops. Small brown head with heavy black body. Foam develops in mouth giving a long sweet aftertaste. (33cl bottle) Will have to have it again to really explore its complexities.

Update: Enjoyed it much better this time. Drank it not too cold to get the full complexity. Looks awesome and tastes similarly.

Acquistata in Belgio da Deca brevery.Birra dal colore marrone scuro,quasi nera.Al naso aromi di caramello invecchiato, anice, mela e ribes in primissimo piano contrastati dauna leggerissima nota di liquirizia.Al gusto il corpo è pastoso.Aroma piacevolmente intenso di frutti scuri,prugna,fico,mela,anice,caramello che lasciano posto infine al tabacco e laffummicato.Ottima

2007 vintage. Popped the cap off this brew and I could see the head and bubbles slowly start to creep up to the top. Poured this beer with a gorgeous free flowing tan  head. The color of the beer is an extremely dark mahogony with some maroon tones coming through. Insane nose on this beer. Believe it or not, I smell Red Bull, liquorice, plum, honey roast, and Coca Cola syrup.  Whoa, is there some carbonation in there! The taste is very remiscent of the nose. More of the dark fruit comes through. Plum, nectarine, great hop bite on the mid-palate, some raison bread, and a melange of dried dark fruit. Not boozy at all. I love this finish. It lingers on without being cloyingly sweet and sticky. I really would like some yeasty artisinal bread, fruit marmalades, and some mild cheese to pair with this beer. I really do just adore this beer. Enough said.
33 cl bottle from 2007. Brown/Amber with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit, slightly sweet, vanilla.

33 cl bottle dark brown colour with tiny persistant head. smell of red fruits,citrus and sugar. taste characterised by caramel notes, malts, banana and some spic notes. provides a moderately alcoholic aftertaste. medum to full body. overall an excellent beer with complex flavours and excellent equilibrium

Bottle.

A - Dark cola brown with a very deep and dark chestnut and ruby hue on the edge. Very large frothy, bubbly sandy almond beige color. Good retention that settles into a nice sticky, foamy layer of lace.

S - Initial aroma has a strong licorice aroma along with plenty of tart dark fruit consisting of plum, prune, fig, and raisin. Some grape aroma is also present. Strong spiced aroma comes out as well with nutmeg and cinnamon being two of the stronger ones. Also has a fairly strong oaky/wine like aroma in the background, and some dark candi sugar comes out too. Interesting and complex aroma with a large variety of aromas.

T - Similar to the nose. Starts off with some licorice, dark candi sugar/molasses. Then some dark fruit with a mix of plum, prune, and fig along with some grape and cherry. These start off somewhat sweet, and then becomes a bit more tart. Fair amount of spiced flavor comes out too. Hints of chocolate come out mid sip. Finishes with a bit more of the oaky/vinous type of taste, and some more sweetness. Like the nose, this is very complex.

M - Medium to full body (a bit closer to full body) with about average carbonation for the style. Pretty smooth and creamy and is a touch drying on the finish.

D - Very drinkable beer. ABV is well hidden and the flavors are very complex which makes me want to drink some more to pick up more flavors. 

Notes: Vintage 2007. Very enjoyable and very complex tasting beer. So many different flavors come out while drinking this, and it has an ever changing taste. ABV is very well hidden as well. Definitely recommend trying this.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2011 1 bottle left from cellar of kulminator NOT panepot but  sluuswachter catzand bruin 1999 
head: small but creamy 
colour: dark brown 
smell: sweet, candy sirup, red fruits ( strawberry ? ) 
taste: candy sugar , fruits , alcohol, bit barley wine like , flaw coffee taste, very very good vintage struise beer , even if it is a subname of pannepot this one was WAY BETTER than aged pannepot much more taste !!! 
thx leen and dirk for sharing !!!

11.2 oz. bottle from Belmont Party Supply.  2007 vintage.  Pours a hazy brown with a ton of foamy tan head initially that dissipates rapidly into a small cap on the beer.  Aroma of caramel and bready malts, nutmeg, raisins, dates, toast, yeast, cocoa, and booze.  Flavor of spices initially turning into tart fruits and finishing with a really unusual leafy, boozy taste.  Also notes of cocoa, caramel, bready malts, earth, dark cherries, plum, and wood.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a mouthfeel that keeps changing.  Dry, boozy, spicy aftertaste.  I can honestly say Ive never had a beer like this before.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, rich dark fruit, spice, & toffee; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums, grapes & cherries), raisons, spice, and bittersweet chocolate; Slight alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very intense - and quite excellent.

2007 vintage. Brown, not much head but good lacing. Complex aroma of malty bread, spice, some oxidazion, stonefruits, banana and a hint of alcohol. Flavour gets a bit of dry cocoa, more spice, more bread and something udefinable that lingers on the back palate, very nice. The mouthfeel starts out a bit weak but then explodes and lingers, interesting. I cant taste the alcohol but I can feel the warmth. A true sipper, perfect with a good book and a nice hunk of camenbert.
2007 vintage. Pours muddy brown. Vinous notes. Nose and taste of sour apple, vinegar, prunes and raisins.

Pours a reddish brown with a small tan head which quickly sinks. Lots of aromas: candy sugar, toffee, bay-leaves, charcoal, coffee, alcohol wine-like. Very complex and attractive, new aromas keep on developping. In the mouth medium bodied with mild carbonation. Nice bitter/sweet mixture, sticky sweet malt balanced out by a long dry warming finish. Amen.

Bottle served in a tulip. 2006 Vintage. Bubbles out of the botttle upon opening. Get a glass quick! Pours hazy, dark brown-red with a medium sized beige-grey head that shrinks to a ring and thin foam top. Little to no lacing. Big fruity aroma full of pepper and spices. Sweet and malty flavor. Bold pit fruit, malt, and chocolate covered cherries. Medium-full body, little carbonation yet fizzy, and a creamy texture. Ultra long, creamy, oily, malt finish. Almost gets a bump just for the impressive length.
Pours black with a small tan head. Huge rich flavour with some dark fruit, chocolate, malt and classic Belgian yeasty flavour to finish it off. Extremely well balanced. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2011 Pretty good strong ale. Poured a hazy dark amber color. Malty and sweet balanced well with the alcohol. Too strong and sweet to quaff many of these in one sitting. But good for a sipping ale on a cold evening.

Drinking the 2010 version right now. Looks the same just flatter. A bit more sharp and bitter. A little bit of chocolate taste with some metallic flavors. Chalky. Bitter aftertaste. Not very spicy.

A: The pour is a dark red-brown color with a solid, creamy tan head on top.

S: A really rich fruity, chocolatey aroma. There are a lot of dark fruits and berries, particularly blueberries and cherries. A really strong malt and bread component as well.

T: The fruity and malty sweetness comes out of the gates strong. There is a bit of chocolate, caramel, and toffee. In terms of fruits, blueberries, red grapes, and cherries. A hint of alcohol as the beer warms.

M: A fairly full bodied beer with a really full and creamy carbonation.

D: You can never go wrong with this one, and Im happy to see how well it holds up to aging. A really fantastic beer and I wish I had bought more.
Nice dark fruit flavors with clove and cinnamon.  Alcohol is balanced well with dark malts and hops.  Slightly bitter finish.  Nice dark brownish red color.  A bit sticky on the finish.
Black as night with dark head. Cherry, spices and hobet in the aroma. Sweet and dark flavor with syrup, honey, spices and cherries balanced well with alcohol.

Enjoyed at the Pub St-Alexandre in Quebec City (in 2008). 2006 bottled edition. Poured a very dark brown colour that was hard to see any highlights. Had a nice coffee-looking top over the brew, and brown sediments at the bottom. Very beautiful aromas of molasse, dark roasted malts and notes of coffee. Full-bodied mouthfeel. The taste was on the dark fruits side, with the alcohol very well-hidden, a nutty finish and a plum-coffee aftertaste (expecially after breathing a while). A very nice Belgian strong ale.

Bottle at the brewery. Very fun, inspiring and interesting to try this one while listening to Carlo Grootaert´s word about this brew and the brewery itself! It pours almout black. Aroma is filled with sweet dark fruits, coffee, dark malt and little spicey. Flavor and the mouth feel is stong and big. It´s burnt malt, brown sugar, dark fruits, coffe and dark chocolate. As sad before it´s round and strong big mouth feel. Complex!

Beer pours a dark opaque brown, with a light tan head that dissipates rather quickly.  The aroma reminds me of a full bodied red wine with complex aromas of bread, grapes, and alcohol.  The beer feels think and hardy on the palate, and is surprisingly smooth.  Flavors of french oak, and coffee are mellowed by the sweetness of malt , and chocolate flavors.   The warming of the alcohol finishes the experience.  This is a fantastic beer.
Bottle 350ml(2008).Color brown with small not lasting brown head. Aroma fruits, spicy, sweet. Taste hints of caramel, fruits, slightly bitter. Full body.
bottle thanks to mar.  poured amberish with an off white head.  aroma was caramel, licorice, and prune.  flavor was the same with a heavy body and low carbonation.

Pours opaque brown/black, huge pillowy tan head that builds and builds, lots of sediment. Aroma of plum, apricot, caramel, funky yeast spice, toffee, citrus, mild roast, mild alcohol. Taste is rich and more fruity with some spiced bread, finishes with bitter hop. Lots of thick malt and yeast. Smooth

Bottled: Aroma is full of molasse, wood, sweetness, malt and acid. Quite sweet flavor, intensive fruity notes of plums and cherries, molasse and wood barrels. Dry astringent and light bitter finish. Quite nice but a hint too sweet.

Wow. Just wow. 2008 bottle. Poured a murky brown with amazing head. Pillowy auburn with bubbles throughout. Interesting. Nose is not totally there - spicy and sweet. In the mouth it’s another story - a perfect, luxurious mouthfeel. Lots of fruit, alcohol, and a velvetly quality that you only get with a truly special beer. A real rolls royce of a beer. The finish is long with a slightly bitter twist. A real treat. About as good as it gets. Funny how the nose gave no indication of what lay ahead. A real journey. De Struise my hat is off, on the floor and awaiting donations from passers by for my next pannepot!

Thanks to CrellMoset for the opportunity to try this great beer! Vintage 2006. Poured into my Chimay Chalice.

A- Beautiful coca-cola brown colored body that pours with a 1 finger off white root beer colored head which has perfect retention and plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is sweet and complex. A cola like scent comes up first with a sugary sweetness. Behind this is a big malt presence and a bit of alcohol.

T- Cola, anise and plum upfront with a substantial bready yeast backbone. A bit of astringent bitterness comes through alogn with a spicy yeast flavor for the finish as the other flavors remain consistent.

P- Wonderful, full, very smooth yeasty body. Low-to-medium carbonation.

O- This is a very nice quad and is probably one of my favorites. Wonderful and complex. Will buy this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-18-2008 02:42:51

33cl bottle. Pours a deep brown color with a thick creamy tan head. The scent was of spices, raisins and malt. A very complex flavor greets you on the first sip, and gets better as the beer warms. The depth of the spiciness, mixed with the aroma made this a very enjoyable experience.

Pours a oily dark brown with a rich and creamy head that dissipates slowly.  Aroma is of plum, cloves, vanilla and spices.  Taste is a muted sweetness with the vanilla and dark fruits combining to give a great flavor.  This is a very smooth beer, silky with a medium to heavy mouthfeel.  Excellent.

Bottle - Vintage 2007. Pours a dark hazy, muddy mahogany brown with a wonderful long-lasting light brown head. Beautiful creamy lacing around the glass. The aroma just jumps out at you, even before picking up the glass. Loads of ripe fruit, plums, prunes, figs, berries, stawberries and cherries with chocolate, caramel and spice. Sweet and delicious flavours of dark chocolate, caramel, ripe-fruit, brown sugar and spice. Silky and creamy across the tongue and an absolute pleasure to drink. I cant wait to try this one again. Absolutely amazing!

From a 2007 bottle. This poured a garnet red that raised big off-white and good lacing    Nose of yeast, ripe fruit, and some cherry,. Full body and rich mouthfeel.  Very rich flavor dominated by the ripe fruit. Slightly sour finish Remarkable stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 (2007 vintage)  Bottle pour to Trappist glass - dark reddish-brown with very long-lasting thick brown head.  Taste very complex with dark fruits changing to chocolate.  Finish just a bit of bitterness but not unpleasing.  Keeps you discovering new things with each swallow.  A little alcohol burn at the end.  Really nice.
Brown of color with a nice brown longlasting head. A nice aroma of spice, sugar, liqurice and dark fruits. A nice flavor of spice, liqurice, tobacco, dark fruits and sugar.

Bottle (Vintage 2005) at Kulminator, Antwerpen. Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and the perfect creamy beige head with an enticing Belgian lace. Wow what an aroma - ripe fruit - berry, plums, prune, blackcurrant, caramel, spice, chocolate and I could go on and on. It really changes in the glass. It takes some time but I finally taste this amazing beer - its perfectly balanced. Dark chocolate with rich fruit and spice mix, caramel, brown sugar and freshly cooked oatmeal bread. Truly remarkable. Its deliciously smooth and bitter that lingers well past the last drop. Put simple its one of the most amazing beers Ive been lucky enough to drink. Beautifully crafted and its aged graciously. 2005 is the perfect year for the Pannepot.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2011 2008(?) Bottle from De Molen. Great beer. Was looking forward to this one and it didnt disappointed me. Pours a black beer with a good brownish head. Impressive aroma with hints of spices, liquorice and dark fruits. Taste is like above with an great mouthfeel and long aftertaste. Such a shame that this beer is a bit hard to get. Would love to drink some more bottles. Beer at its best. 042010

330 ml bottle in Germany from shrubber85. Pours a dark black with a full brown head. Aroma is malt and a burning alcohol smeel. Taste is a chocolate, malt, ecoliptus and coffee mix. Palate is also malty and not as offensive as expected. A pleasant and excellent beer.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice and orange.

Vintage 2007 from John @ AbsofBeerTV.  WOW!! Thanks!  Pours brown with a tan head.  Aromas of brown sugar and spice.  Flavors of fig, spiced apple, molassas and toffee which linger on the palate for minutes.  Alcohol was well integrated.  Overall just an Awesome beer.

2007 bottle...An amazing texture and presence on the palate.  A substantial dark ale with roasted cherry flavor sits behind a restrained wild yeast mild sourness.  All 10% of the alcohol is undetectable.  Was excited to get my paws on this bottle and it lives up to its rating.
sweet dark malty,red/brown, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation.
A dark and even for Belgian beers rather sweet beer. The taste is full of raisins, dark prune and burned notes. Its smooth and gentle and might go well with some (not too sweet) dessert.

A beautiful one. So dense and velvety. It is syrupy sweet and delicius. It is remind me of nutwine. The nose is fantastic. Dark fruits ans spices smells. It slips into the groove without difficulty. Very delicate body.

33 cl bottle. 2007 Vintage

Aroma: Sweet with a hint of yeast, fruits and caramel. Not the best, but complex and alluring.

Appearance: Almost black in the glass  with a moderatly thick, cream colored head.

Taste: Sweet and pleasant with a sting of bitterness just towards the end of the sip. In the aftertaste youll find a hint of coffee and honey that lingers for quite a while.

Palate: Lightly carbonized and creamy makes the honey taste protrude and intesify.

Overall: Splendid beer that all should taste.

Beer at its best. Aroma is a complex sweet one with spices, caramel, chocolate, coffee, raisin, and a slight sense of vanilla. Pours with a nice tanned head and ruby, brownish color. Tastes medium sweet, almost like a dessert beer. Medium body with creamy texture and a well-balanced carbonation. Overall my favorite, and will be hard to beat. A well deserved Thank you goes to De Struise Brouwers.

33cl bottle vintage 2007. Gusher. Deep black color with a creamy brown head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is full of dried fruits with malts and some touches of pepercake and bread. Taste is sweet and malty with chocolate, coffee and touches of dried fruits and hops. The aftertaste is light bitter with some sweet pepercake and coffee. Mouthfeel is smooth and sticky with decent carbonization. The flavors are perfectly balanced. The mother of one of the greatest beer series in the world!  Magnificent!

This is the 2008 vintage. Pours dark brown, almost black with one inch tan head that fades at a decent pace. Nose is amazing, complex dark malt with deep, vinous, dried fruits, some chocolate and coffee, bready malt, and some spices, light rum notes and a light oak character with mild soy sauce and light alcohol. In the mouth, deep fruits, caramel sweetness with some bitter chocolate on the swallow and a light, lingering sweetness and a mild tingling burn on the tongue. This is an incredible beer, though I prefer the Grand Reserva.

Egészen sötétvörös színe van, még a lámpa elé tartva is alig lehet átlátni rajta.Közepesen nagy,világosbarna hab gerjed rajta kitöltés közben,ami nem tart ki sokáig,de azért egy kis csipke terítőt hagy a sör tetején.Illata édeskés,gyógyfüves,gyümölcsös és egy picit tejcsokis.Igen összetett és különleges íze van.Ott van az alkohol édessége a komló kesernyéssége,házi szilvalekvár,karamellás étcsokoládé és egy csipet kávé.Ezek kergetőznek egymást váltva a szájban,miközben kellemesen csipkednek az apró buborékok.Közepesen testes és az alkohol tartalom finoman melegít és zsibbaszt.Utóíze medvecukros,kesernyés és kiszárítja a szájpadlásunkat.Egy igazi klasszis,remek választás egy fárasztó nap után relaxáláshoz vagy egy jó könyvhöz. / Én éppen a "Maláta" antológiát olvasgatom mellette. /

The color is very brown almost black. The head is creamy and rather modest.
The sweet aroma offers hard roasted malt and plums.
In the taste there are notes of hard roasted malt, plums, sourish berries, banana, liquorice and a little touch of forest floor.
The alcohol gives a rounded warmth like with a good sherry. The mouthfeel is soft and very full-bodied.
This is nothing but worldclass. Pannepot is fully up to the hights of westvleteren 12.

Dark amber in color with a beige head that leaves a nice lacing around the glass.  Smell is of brown sugar, green apple, dark fruit and caramel. Caramel and toffee first greet the tongue, followed by spicy phenols and dark fruit.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation and a nice, dry finish.  Definitely have to say the regular Pannepot is my favorite vs. the other various aged versions.

Well if this isnt a World Classic, I dont know what is.  Maybe now that it has 1000 ratings on RateBeer, its rightful place in The Pantheon cannot be denied.  Beautifully dense, velvety brown syrup appearance with a formidable tan head.  Rich and inviting aroma with an incredible assortment of malt characteristics, including toffee and toasted gingerbread/fruitcake elements, nicely kept in check by a zesty, zippy sparkle from the high carbonation.   Delicious, dessert-like brown sugar flavors with figs, dates, a spiced-and-spicy undercurrent (cinnamon, artisan bread, ginger crisp cookies, a touch of anise seed, peppery alcohol), and just enough yeasty tanginess to balance the dizzying malt array.  Even touches of rauchmalt smoke and tobacco.  Lots of delightful sugary accents (toasted treacle, molasses) without being cloying-- the carbonation does wonders.  Long and lovely finish with beautiful, relatively high carbonation for the boldness and gravity.  Perfect structure.  The yeast shot adds a bit of a dirty punch to the pepper, and displays a still-new, bolder layer (and the real culprit?) to this complex medley.  Sublime.
Dark brown with a thick frothy head. Apricot, candi sugar. Taste-apricot, peaches, malty, slight sourness in the finish. Very complex. Full bodied and a great texture.  Pretty much perfect.

Appearance:Big brown head, deep brown/red colour.
Aroma: Sweet, spices, esthers, licorice sweet candies.

Flavour: Sugar, lots of it, alcohol, roasted malts, dried fruits, honey, sweetness a bit overpowering.
Mouthfeel: Smooth and full bodied.

Total: Not a bad beer, but considering the hype a disappointment, too much sugar in this one.

2007 Bottle from MrPickles...thanks Andy--deep mahogany pour, nearly black, with nice rosy highlights and a light tan head. Dark fruit, oak, and red wine on the nose--very vinous. Rum and whiskey, dark fruit, dark chocolate, and finishes with a dry, oaky, bloodlike flavor (thanks Pepsican). Hides the 10%, and smooth. A nice beer, but not one that evokes poetry.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2014 Pours a dark chocolate brown color with a generous head.  Has a very complex aroma that has hints of caramel, currant, roasty malt, vinegar, oak, and slight hops, each sublte and none overpowering.  As good as the aroma is, the taste is even better.  A very complex taste of of bitters, sweet, and malt, with a nice touch of oak and sour on the finish.  Love the taste of this beer.  Again very complex in aroma and taste, but none of the characteristics overpowers.  Has a creamy mouth feel.

Pours a dark brown with a nice red tinge and has a good amount of sediment floating in it - a good sign that this will referment inside the bottle. The smell is of roasted malts, sugar, apples, plums, and light malts, very nice indeed. The taste is amazingly complex and encompasses green apples, plums, brown sugar, with the slightest sting of alcohol. Probably one of the smoothest brews Ive ever had

2007 bottle. Pours reddish brown with thin tan head, aroma is full of spices especially cardamom, dark fruit, and sweetness. Taste is complex, with spices, dark fruit, sweetness that goes into a slight sour funk, maybe Brett added? Excellent brew, with a little sour touch on the end.

Bottle, 2007 vintage. Slow gusher. Beautiful looking beer, dark dark brown with a pillowy white head. I get lots of plums and cherries in the smell with some candy cane and  belgian yeast some caramel too. Taste is sweet but not overwhelmingly so, very well balanced as the sweetness is cut off by the alcohol. Palate is perfect, rich and chewy.

Bottle, thanks Vaiz! Thick black pour, large tanned head, nice lacing.
Aroma is fruity, malty, some liquorice and bark.
Wild ride of flavour, bitter hops, sweet fruits, some coffee and smoke.
Very nice.

Great beer with a week aroma however. The taste is much better and interesting. Taste of caramel and spices and a hint of coffea.This is the 2007 and looking forward to the 2006 as well which I have bought as well.

Bottle at home. Pours almost black with a creamy tan head that quickly dissipates but leaves some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, fruits and licorice. The flavor starts off fruity and sweet but then quickly moves to a more bitter presence with licorice and some hops. Very nice complex flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 Very dark brown, almost black beer. Nice head, foam seems to last forever. Nice aromas comming to my nose. Looks very tasty. Good strong taste with a bit of "drop"-taste it seems. The taste changes when you nip till you swallow, very complex. Very much sweetness, and a nice oily-sticky mouthfeel. Really like this one. Also the aftertaste holds for a long time, and even that one seems to change. Without a doubt a great beer. Fruity, but on a nice way. Sweetness is a big part of this beer.

Edit: At 10 sept 2010 tasted a 2004 version. So 6 years old. A bit lighter it seems at the first sight. Still a good sized head, smells more earthy and a bit weird burned. Prunes comes trough. Smell is less then a fresh one in my opinion. Very sweet, really more sweet then expected. Taste prunes, chocolate, fruits. Very complex, maybe even complexer then a fresh one. Caramel, sucre, sucre, sucre, but also other tastes comes up to make it that complex, but to much sweetness for sure. I slightly prefer a fresh one, that is more balanced. But even this one is still a good beer ofcourse. Both (fresh and aged) just maybe got a bit to much sugar in it.

2006 bottle...holy god am I ever impressed by this beer. The nose and flavors brim with figs, raisins, plums, cola and toffee. Mouthfeel is a tad on the thin side but appropriate for the style. If I had a St. Bernardus and a Westy 12 in front of me, I have little doubt that I would favor this in a blind tasting. Happy to have a few of these in the cellar.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2010 Been waiting a long ol time for this.
Not a gusher, but almost no liquid on the pour. Enormous tan head, like a milkshakes froth. Airy, fine, wonderful. Lasts til the very end. Beer itself is black. Bready aroma of spices, rich caramel malts, ginger, cake. Nuanced and complex. Rich, huge flavor. Rich, bready malts. Sweet but not cloying. Meal-like. Acidic cherries matched with all kinds of dried fruits and plums. Body is lighter and thinner than you expect. Very silky. You almost want more of a bite. Big alcohol. Slightly roasty woodiness in the finish.

Bottle.  A dark brown to blackish color with a creamy light brown head.  A rich fruit filled chocolate aroma.with figs, sugar, raisins, and light spices rounding out the flavors.  A delicious beer through and through.

2007 bottle.  Been wanting to try this for a while.  Dark brown/black pour with a big light tan head.  Fantastic big aroma of cherries and dark fruits with a barrel aged warmth to it.  Flavor is dark fruits, nuts, brown sugars and a musty quality.  Finishes up sour and bitter.  Soda-like late arriving carbonation.  Not what I expected for some reason.  Definitely seems like a beer that could change with age.  Has a bit of an antiseptic feel to it.

33cl bottle purchased at La Cervezateca in Barcelona.  I think this cost me 4 Euros (about $5.50.  Its important to note that La Cervezateca had two different bottles of this.  One bottle had been shipped directly from Belgium to Barcelona.  The other had been distributed by Shelton Bros, meaning it was sent to the US and then back to Barcelona for sale.  Needless to say, I bought the bottle less traveled.  Pours a nearly opaque, deep, dark brown, nearly black with garnet edges and a thin, creamy beige head.  Aroma is very nice, prunes, plums, raisins, alcohol, yeast, bread, light spice.  Flavor is nice, yeasty, bready, prunes, raisins, some dark chocolate, toasted grains, a little bit of alcohol.  Finish is full bodied with some lasting sweetness.  Nose is very nice, flavor is a bit of a downgrade.

I waited long enough to try this, and damn it was awesome.  33cl bottle poured into a snifter a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma was utterly superb.  Fig, dates, plum, malts, slight amounts of chocolate.  Taste is full of the dark fruit, belgian yeast, malty character.  The palate is just dominated by this beer and it was glorious.  One of the best.

Bottle.  Strong caramel and vanilla aroma with floral notes.  Pours a dark brown with a camel head.  Oaky and smoky.  The malt is quite strong making it a sweet beer.  Nice for a good winters evening.

2007. Wow. After trying a couple of other beers in the Pannepot family, I was beginning to wonder what the hype was about, but this beer is truly awesome. It pours a deep brown, almost black, with hints of red. A persistent tan head tops it off. The aroma is quite sweet - caramel, roast, maple syrup, leather, apricot and plum. The flavor is even more impressive, and changes shape several times after taking a sip. First a wave of malty, dark fruit sweetness hits, followed by the tang of red wine, and finally chocolate and the tiniest hint of booze in the finish. Thick, creamy body. This is the first beer Ive tried that I might call a successful stout/belgian strong crossover, though the belgian characteristics dominate. Truly outstanding. The best beer Ive had in a while.
Bottle. A must have brew.  Tons if sour,  cocoa,  graham,  vanilla,  dark fruits up in this brew.  So money and one of the best strong ales.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2010 Wow this beer just makes you want to sit back relax and contemplate. A superb beer. Lovely bubbly creamy head poured into trappist style glass from 33cl bottle bought with many thanks from BeerMerchants.com

A very heavy full bodied tar texture; reminiscent of Rochefort. Complex aroma of dried fruits, marzepan and spices. Can taste roasted malts; caramel, licroish, dried fruits and figgs. Similar to Rochefort in complexity. Please kids dont down this baby. Its a cool slow long one. 

Maximum respect for De Struise. Awesome mouth feel and very balanced despite the complexity. I can hint brown sugar too. WOW. I need a De Struise glass.
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2010 Another fantastic beer from Struise. I prefer the 2007 version than the 2008 one. Spicy with dark fruits flavors. Onctuous and easy to drink.

2007 vintage. Pours a deep dark red brown, almost black with an nice thick beige head.  Aroma is fruity and floral, roasted malts and caramels, candy and spices.  Flavors of roasted malts, molasses, coffee, black chocolate, some dry fruits like raisins and plums, and a good note of earth like oak.  Good carbonation with a sweet and sourness finish. A persistant earthy oak taste lasting in mouth with a touch of liqueur. 
Extremely complex and well ballance, warm heavy beer.  To drink very slowly, such a wonderful bevarage.
Una volta ho bevuto una bottiglia del 2006 ke assomigliava a una westvleteren 12!! grandissima birra!

Pours very very dark brown, almost black. Small beige head. Malty aroma, slightly sweet taste, hints of coffee and chocolate. Very complex palate. Very very very good beer that one could easily rank among the worlds best beers!

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2011 Bottle split with Pat. Bottle. Pours deep, deep brown, with a nice beige head. Aroma of raisins, candy apple, scotch, vinegar, malts, yeast, and caramel. Medium body with a warming finish. This beer is extremely well balanced; with flavors perfectly complementing one another.
Very nice Belgian.  Dark brown with a small head.  Aroma is strong of malt and alcohol.  Taste is malt, molasses, vanilla and an alcohol warmth.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2009 2007 vintage to celebrate rating #150: Dark brown, almost black in colour with a beige head. Incredibly complex aroma: the first thing that came to my mind was blueberries and cherry syrup; dark caramel malts and peppery spices, wood and sherry. Tastes very sweet, usually people describe roasted malt flavours as dark chocolate, but this reminds me more of sweet milk chocolate. Raisiny malty goodness with a lovely, distinct berry-like fruitiness that is elevated by the alcohol. Im amazed how clean and accessible this beer remains at 10% ABV. Simply a masterpiece.
This beer starts off with a really nice nose of yeast, dark fruit, alcohol, and hints of chocolate.  Flavors are similar, but not quite as strong or as flavorful as the nose.  Overall, a nice beer.
I think that this version of pannepot is the best of all. Very smooth at all and absolutely one of my favourites. Just a half step over the others.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours very alluring dense and dark mahogany, with generous off-white head. Extremely complex aroma of sweet dark fruits, chocolate, liquorice, spices and caramel. Quite sour on the palate, slighty too much so for me (compared to the Reservas), but a cracking ale nonetheless.

My #500!
Bottle from Ölbutikken, Copenhagen.

Losts of licorice,chocolate, spices!

You can realy tell that this is the base beer for the reserva and grand reseva.
Bottle. Ar: Raisin, spices, chcocolate. Fla: Raisin, spices, chcocolate, licorice. Pal: Smooth.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Bottle. 11.2 oz. (2007 Vintage) Pours deep, deep brown, nearly opaque, with a finger, beige head. Aroma of raisins, apples, wine, scotch, vinegar, malts, yeast, and caramel. Medium body with a beautiful, warm blossom in the finish. This brew is perfectly balanced; sour and sweet are balanced; heavy and smooth alike. Outstanding Belgian strong, and, thus far, one of my favorite brews that I have sampled. Highly recommended.

From bottle at Cambrinus. Mellow rich sweet aroma. Malty with roasted grain, overripe plum and bitter hops. A bit of fruity esters but not a lot going on in the nose. Dark brown black clear with thin tan head. Medium-heavy body with medium carbonation. Starts sweet and malty with plum and macerated fruit tang. Alcohol warming with medium bitter finish. Roasted grain or barley. A bit thin at the finish.

Deep brown pour, tons of sediment. Starts with a fizzy head but quickly fades and leaves no lacing. Aroma was incredibly complex. Quite boozy with tons of sweetness, mainly molasses. Some hints of coffee and a spicy yeastness. Flavor had a bit more caramel sweetness and an unexpected tartness to it. Reminds me a little of  brandy. Right out of the fridge the palate was fizzy and lively, however, it becomes extremely soft and mellow as it warms. Mostly my fault for not being able to wait for a proper temperature.

Opaque with a boozy and soapy aroma. in the mouth it is the most undeniable beautiful thing. Thick mollases are met with smooth vanilla and wooded brightness. Vinous and porty. Walnuts and prunes. Were there.

2006 vintage.

Very dark brown with a minimal pale beige head that settles instantly and leaves basically no lacings.

Sweet malts and lots of fruit aromas (mostly plums and currants) in the nose. Prominent but mild spiciness. Woody notes, a hint of chocolate and some alcohol. A pleasant and balanced smell, but its somewhat restrained - its almost like its character is too round.

The taste is basically just more of the same. Lost of sweet malts and rich flavors of fruits (plums, cherries, currants). Dark bread. Hints of chocolate, a general woody flavor and pleasant spices (reminiscent of Christmas spices). Some earthy yeast (that really gets bigger when the yeast sediments are poured into the glass, the yeast in this one really packs a lot of flavors). For some reason, in all the versions if Pannepot Ive had, I think I pick up a taste that reminds me of Coca Cola, dont know how to describe it in any other way though. A light, not very tangy, tart note and some grassy hops in the middle. The finish is gently bitter with a decent amount of sweet alcohol and some wood, raisins, cherries and spices.

Rather full-bodied, very smooth texture. Mild carbonation.

A good beer. Tasty and balanced with a very round character. I really like how well the sweet malts and fruit esters go with the spices in this one. But overall, the flavors are a little too round and it almost feels like the beer holds back a little. I wonder how if would come out if everything was turned up a notch of two.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
2007 bottle. Mahogany color with plenty of sediment, would likely be a reddish-brown without the sediment. dry fruit, sugar, coffee in aroma. Velvety mouthfeel. Superb.

2006 vintage, poured into a St. Bernardus goblet.  Pours a deep mahogany with small tan head that fully dissipates.  Aroma is very rich and sweet...brown sugar, molasses, dark fruit (raisins, dates, prunes), booze, and a touch of vinegar.  Taste is sweet, with creamy smooth mouthfeel and a boozy finish.  Delicious!

12 oz bottle.  A mellow aroma, yet rich and complex at the same time. Interesting notes of fruity strawberry shortcake, with light bit of funk stand out to me. Also, some prominent yeasty dark malts and nutty toffee, with light candy sugars, and some minor wine qualities. The pour had a medium-large soft, pillowy caramel cream head, a full body, and a dark amber brown color. Theres a very nice rich sweetness to this beer that is not unlike an expensive piece of candy youd find wrapped in a box. Besides the slight hint of alcohol, this beer feels nowhere near 10% abv even with all the flavors. The feel overall has a lot of sugar crystal qualities to it, but this is mixed with a good full creaminess to add to the uniqueness of this beer. Notes on this one definitely lean toward the malty sweetness, but its really in no way unbalanced . It starts out with a more deep , caramel-toffee, brown sugar cake sweetness, then gives way to some darker fruits, light olive and cheese, toasted malts, and light woody hops in a drier than expected finish. This beer definitely proves its world class status, but didnt separate itself at all (like I was hoping) from the Pannepøt, which I also thoroughly enjoyed.

2006 Bottle...  Poured hazy brownish with a thick, greyish/slightly tan head.  Aroma of toasty sugars, floral fruits, and tart yeast.  Really wonderful brew.  Slight bitterness, roasted grains, dried fruits and coffee.  Raisins, and wine-like, port qualities.  Dry finish.
Based on recent memory of the slashed-O version, I dont think theres much difference.  This is definitely good stuff, but I wasnt blown away.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2012 6th March 2010. 2005 Vintage at Kulminator. Opaque black beer. Lovely fruity nose with a hint of sour. Softish palate. Sweet and fruity - some blackcurrant and a whisper of pear. Milk chocolate blends with the fruit perfectly. 2004 Vintage at Kulminator. Clear brown beer. Light dry palate. Fruity but also dusty. A poor sibling to the 2005 - decent but less fruity and the chocolate is almost absent.  2009 Vintage at Gainsbar, Kortrijk. Sweet spicy malt with a little pear and a trace of bubblegum, think this one could really mature well.30th July 20102006 VintageCloudy dark brown beer, frothy tan head. Yeasty marmite nose. Semi crisp, semi dry palate. Starts with marmite and then coca cola. Touch of chocolate before a little spice. Finishes dry with a little aniseed. Nice complex beer, just a bit too much marmite. 3.530th July 20102007 VintageCloudy dark brown beer, frothy tan head. Light palate, semi dry. Pretty much the same as the 2006 but with the marmite less dominant. 3.5.30th July 20102008 VintageOpaque black beer, thick tan head Light palate, semi dry. Low carbonation. Smooth lightly spiced dark malt. A little chocolate. Minerals. A little coca cola and a whisper of coffee. 3.6

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2009 Struise Schooltje, Vleteren. Dark brown  beer, beautifull looking. Aroma is complex, sweet, toasty and spicey. Taste is very long. The beer is sweet, bitter with a fine coffee flavour. it ends with fine bitters and hints of chocolate.
Fantastic beer. Merci Carlos

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown, hazy beer, medium beige head that lasts. Smells like everything: spices, dark fruits, sweet (sugar), caramel and I think I forgot something to mention. The smell is also lovely complex: dark fruits, malty and light sweet in the mouth, followed by some caramel, coffee, chocolate (choose what you want) in the background, and finishing with spices. Full body, and the aftertaste stays long in the mouth. Formidastic!

2006 Bottle (3 yrs old).  Slightly dry fruit, cherry nose.  Very deep brown with light white/tan effervescent head.  A sweet/alcohol balance with dry fruit and cherries carrying the flavor.  Very much a quad-esque beer with its fruit, sweetness and light spiciness.

8/2/2009 sampled bottle with a 2006 vintage...

pours opaque and super dark brown... bordering black with a two inch orange tinted creamy brown head. loads of drippy lacing stays behind. 

the aroma is quite profound...so many layers... its really bready, floral, fruity and herbaceous... cinnamon, chocolate, raisins, brown sugar, molasses, clove, cardamom, star anise, vinous/red wine and something numbing bordering menthol/camphor. 

i wish the flavor matched the aroma... it is fairly sweet on the palate. mixed with fruitiness and a wine-like tartness it seems distracted... notes similar to the aroma... but not quite. there is a bit of ashiness in the far background, some cooked orange peel,  a bit of toasty nuts/coffee, skunky grassy hops and lots of spice (mainly cinnamon) in the aftertaste. alcohol pinches at the sinus on the finish.

it is medium bodied with a noticeable yeasty grit in the texture. however,  im in love with how soft, lush and airy the mouth feel is... 9/5/7/4/16/4.1

Black with a thick tan head. Aroma is wonderfully sweet and spicy. There is a lot going on here, raisins, chocolate, cinnamon, cardamom, a hint of espresso. Flavor is just as complex, and yet very mellow. All those fruity, spicy flavors blend together perfectly. Mouthfeel is light and airy. I love it!

Intens dark ale, almost black with red highlights and creamy beige head on top. Aroma is super complex, with a rich malty character and touches of coffee and dried fruits. On the pallet is full and very tasty, it has a stout touch but also very quad like at the same time. Aftertaste is long, complex, fruity and at some point coffee and chocolate like.
A tuely outstanding beer.

2007 vintage.  Pour was overly heady even with a rather unagressive trickle.  took a long time to settle.  While I like thick head, this one crossed the line into annoyingly big and stubborn.  Scent is semi acetic sourness over dark fruits and yeast.  Taste is of rasins, bread, and booze with some light spice and a tiny tiny sour hint.  Reminds me of something inbetween Westy 12 and 8, a bit too boozy for my tastes.  Mouth however is good, thick and medium carbonation.

2007 Vintage. Pours a dark brown with brown (not just tan) head. Aroma is malt, sweet malt. This is a very sweet beer. One reason I dont really like it. Dont get me wrong, its a beautiful beer. It smells great and honestly isnt bad. But its too much of a sugarbomb for me. There is a deep flat malt flavor in this, strong in molasses flavor. Some folks love that, I do not.  Dried prunes, dried apricots, dried raisins and dried dates - thats the makeup of this beer.

Pours deep brown, Thin head low retention. Some suspended sediment. Great aroma very bready, lots of dark fruit. Excellent deep rich flavour. Fruit, bread, almost a port flavour. really great tasting!

2005 Vintage at Kulminator in Antwerpen. 

Beautiful appearance with the dark, almost black color. Head was white and creamy. Great fruity aroma, spices, yeast.  Wonderful taste with many different ingredients. Caramel, dried fruit, spices, biscuits, raisins, licorice. Full of bubbles and complex. A wonderful beer!

Poured from the bottle to a dark brown with slight reddish tint, and a thin off white head that klingers thru mid-glass. Aroma is malty dark fruit with and the mouthfeel is like a muted Flemish Sour...tangy at first, then slowly turning sweet. Taste brings out the dark fruits of the nose, all rounding to a long, pleasant finish.

Pours a dark semi clear with a reddish brown hue with thick sudsy bubble floating on the top, very good head. While it faded quick it was good looking for a while. The nose is full of sour notes mainly raspberry blended with caramel. As you sip on it the flavor is very acidic and contains black current and it is full of dark fruits. it is a bit herbal and fruity. The finish is nice and subtle and dry, very similar to a weak merlot with hints of blackberry. Overall the carbonation fades quick. Cheers to Drink4Satan for sharing this with me
Bottle from 07 pours a dark brown color with a small off white head. Has a dark fruit smell to it. Has a nice yeast, dark fruit, and maybe a little spice taste to it.

nice dark brown with thick frothy dark tan head.
heavy aroma of intense dark fruit -- dried cherries, prunes, raisins -- and lots of alcohol, with a deep roasty sweetness and mild spice. also lots of chocolate milk.
flavor is similar -- like a spiced cherry/strawberry chocolate milk. 
silky medium body, nice carbonation.
as it warms the aroma deepens to a strong wine with roasty coffee and cinnamon.
this is the best.

Aroma is wonderful, kind of similar to Westvleterens 8 and 12. Dough, red wine, blackcurrant and cinnamon. The taste doesnt live up to the aroma, but its still good. Raisins, chocolate, spices, nuts, yeast, soil and dried fruit. Finish is dry and with a little bit of alcohol. This is a truly vinous brew, slightly acidic and with lively carbonation.

Aroma of dough, liquorish, red wine, black current, cinnamon and dust. Appearance is dark brown with medium brown head. Flavor of raisins, black current, liquorish, malt, species and hints of yeast. The alcohol is warming. The palate is very thick. Overall a very interesting beer with lots of taste.

Serving: 330 ml bottle. 2007 vintage.
Appearance: Extremely dark brown with hazy ruby highlights and a monstrous foamy tan head.  The head lasts for ages and the alcohol leaves nice legs on the glass.
Aroma: As soon as you pop the top, a wonderful fruity aroma fills the room.  Rich, dark fruit notes with touches of currant, cherry, and apple.  Yeast, dust, clove, and spice all add to the mix.  Fantastic!  It has a nice, dry earthiness in the background as well.
Flavor: Rich, yet light and dry all at the same time.  Warming alcohol, a fruity tartness, yeasty dust, some earth, loads of spice, and a slight touch of oxidation on the tongue.  Very complex stuff.  A slight medicinal note emerges towards the middle of the beer.  Bits of raisin, mace, cardamon, and just enough sweetness to help balance all of the flavors.  
Palate: High, champagne like carbonation that is very fine on the tongue.  Medium, slightly dry mouthfeel with a medium-long, spiced finish.
Overall: I can see why this one is so highly rated.  Truly a stand out beer and a must try for everyone.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2013 7/4/7/4/13[3.5]

At BQ Birra in Milan, 2007 bottle, dark almost black liquid with a medium mocca color head, powerful aroma of raisins, nuts, chocolate, brandy and cherry liquor, flavor of nuts, caramel, dried fruits, warming pleasant alcohol and a nice acidity towards the end, full bodied, excellent beer. 9/5/8/5/116[4.3]

Thanks again to STLWill for this generous offering. The pour produces a ruby edged mahagony with a puffy, airy tan head with good retention, dimpling as it fades. The nose is musty, seemingly tart, with some mild acetic notes, tart fruits, raisins, and subdued cocoa. The flavour is equally musty, dry, with herbal hops, anise, cardamom, raisins, and alfalfa sprouts. The palate is like velvet, though it is eqauly airy and warming. Perfect for the style. Unfortunately, there is a detectable astringency in the finish, though the way it melds with the rest of the flavours, it can be considered a tasteful character of the beer.

2007 bottle. Cloudy amber pour with a medium tan head. Spicy aroma with anise, booze and some tart fruit. Dark fruit flavor up front with some tartness and a nice spicy finish. Very nice and lives up to the hype.

Reminded me a fair amount of Adam, but not quite as odd, and more clearly Belgian. Tons of smooth powdery cocoa chocolate, with the tiniest bit of wood. Raisin and plum in up front in the nose, and some in the finish as well. Fairly high carbonation. Ridiculous smooth. Great palate. A bit of an odd twang in the finish that was not so great.

Pours dark reddish brown with a nice creamy, tan head, but rather short lasting. Good lacing. Malty nose with spices and dark fruit. Flavour with malt, raisins and plums. Full bodied. Ends up more dry. A very enjoyable brew.

Bottle 2007 from beerman6866 and a DLD trade. poured brown and cloudy,lots of floaters the head was tan with lots of tight little fizzy bubbles that you could hear popping like the fizz from a coke ( a beautiful sound ) armas of dark friuts,malts,yeast, and spices flavors of the same with licoriceand caramel, the finish was smooth and sweet and a little tart GFB

did a head to head with this, the reserva and the grand reserva and this was my favourite.  A very drinkable yet incredibly rich and flavourful brew.  A slight wine character to it.  Very fruity dark fruits.  Awesome brew

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2010 2008 bottle. Consumed April 2010. A dark brown to black beer with an amazing head that is very big and fluffy. This head does not want to go away and then very slowly falls. The aroma is nice and fruity, almost like dried fruit, berries, and maybe even a dash of chocolate. The taste is very fruity, yeast, maybe even some slight roast in there and it prickles the tongue with a lot of carbonation. I really like its fruitiness. This beer has a lot of flavor to offer yet it is super smooth and goes down to easy for 10% ABV that is totally hidden. This is quite the Belgian beer and really is a masterpiece. Simply wonderful. This is an updated rating.

Dark brown colour with a huge tan head. The aroma of malt, liquorice and dark fruits. The flavour is very sweet, malt, spices, berries and liquorice. Aftertaste is sweet and vinous. Full-bodied and very smooth.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2010 (bottle, 2007) pours a very dark ruby colour with a creamy brown head and great lacing. sweet aroma of freshly puréed strawberries and caramel, with light hints of vanilla, cornflakes, herbs and alcohol. flavour is another burst of strawberries, with some raisins, caramel, light notes of dark chocolate and coffee and a long roasted-grainy, lightly warming finish. strong-bodied, quite sweet, with smooth carbonation. alcohol is well-hidden.

Great head to start and leaves a dense thin layer of bubbles.  Light lace.  Dark brown and muddy.

Mild aroma of darker (perhaps crystal) malts, although it is hard to detect.

Strong waming, alcoholic taste--much like a fine sherry.  Full bodied with a lower level of carbonation than many Quads.  This is a very smooth beer.  Worthwhile to seek out.

Small bottle, gift from a friend.  Pours a deep mocha brown with a massive beige/ tan head that left some spotty lacing.  Belgian candy sugar, cherry, toasted malts and maybe a bit of cocoa powder on the nose.  Very sweet flavor.....I get candied dark fruits, slight cocoa, brown sugar and a bit of booze on the back end.  Finishes medium-full in body, quite coating on the palette.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2010 Bottle from the Hopduvel. Pours a nice dark beer. Very rich flavour but too spiced for my palate. I would prefer a cleaner version of this beer. Still a very interesting beer.
Second time I had this the experience was very different. I even enjoyed the spiciness now. 
Score first tasting: 3.6 Second tasting: 4.0 => 3.8

2006 label with a very cool painting of a pannepot, which is defined as a fishing boat in the descriptive text of the label. The color is black and the head is short white-tan bubbles. The smell is a little sweet and syrupy with a little black licorice but not cloying in the least. First taste was gum, who knows what type, and spices and a little sweetness, pretty good. I wonder what spices they used because while the beer tastes spiced, I sure cant pick them out individually. This one is a monster because it seems to foam up in my mouth and is going to take a while but the flavors are good, which is all that matters to me. Good stuff.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-07-2007 17:50:41

2007 Bottle.  A slightly sour fruity front with a rich nutty malty character.  Slightly purple hued with a thin creamy tan head that clings in a wide swath to the edge of the glass.  Flavor is very rich, quite tart with a backbone of chocolate nutty malt.  Very foamy higly carbonated feel.  Dry lingering tartness.  Quite good, interesting.

Bottle @ Ebenezers. Pours deep brown into a snifter. Tan head with excellent retention leaves slow sheets.  Pit fruit and malt aromas. Full and sweet with dark dried fruits upfront, turning slightly sour and peppery in the lasting finish.

Pours a beautiful deep red/brown but already Im slightly perturbed by the head, nice tan colour but looks a bit fizzy.  The nose is good, smells just like fresh bread dough interlaced with spices.  Now for the bad bit, unfortunately my bottle was very overcarbonated.  I know thats the risk you take with bottle conditioning (& one well worth taking too) & everyone else seems to really rate it so I guess I was just unlucky, but the fizziness completely wiped out any flavour & body in the mid palate.  I can see underneath some fantastic deep fruit with eastern spices & a terrific sweet/sour balance.  The finish is very long as well, with those spices subtley lingering, but Ill just have to crack open another bottle, worse things happen at sea.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a huge tan head. The aroma of malt, liquorice and dark fruits. The flavour is very sweet, malt, spices, berries and liquorice. Aftertaste is sweet and vinous. Full-bodied and very smooth. Very good, aging would probably make this even better.
The spices in this beer were off the hook. I loved this beer.  I could drink it all the time. well, as a night cap really.

The aroma of this beer is somewhat subtle, in that it is not one of the "in-your-face" variety.  It is cherry and ripe plum.  The head is definitely espresso colored and thin, but it is long lasting with good lacing.  I notice the carbonation right away with a chocolate flavor initially.  The flavor mellows out and becomes somewhat sour in aftertaste.  I dont notice the spices that are added and I find this a good thing.  The alcohol is noticeable, but also very subtle.  Coloring is very dark, rich brown.  Overall, the flavor is very fruity.  Ive tasted a lot of beers that were more appealing.

Tasted at the Cambrinus in Brugge.  My current favorite beer.  Pours a dark red/brown with smallish head.  Nose of cherry, plum, strawberry.  Taste starts out with a little milk chocolate and cream.  Turns sour toward the end with some coffee and berry notes.  Took a few bottles of this one home.
2007 bottle. Pours black with a big tan head. Aroma is sour apple, dark fruit, and spice. Flavor is sweet malts, spice, light apple, and a good bit of alcohol.

Bottle at the Beer Engine into tulip.  Pours dark black with 1.5 inch tan head that fades quickly.  Smells like a lambic with all those white grapes on the nose but the taste is outrageous.  The first 10 times I sipped it, the aftertaste was OYSTERS!  WHAT!  I love oysters but never expected them in my beer!  Huge carbonation buzzing around on the lips and the front of the palate at first.  The 10% which I saw classified as 11.2% @ BEngine, was definitely not hidden and was pretty boozy.  Whoa, take your sweet time with this puppy and get some oysters.
Love these bottles. Two year old bottle. So smooth and sweet and enjoyable. Lots of dark rich fruit with a rich body. A nice level of sweet chocolate and cherry. A sipper and worth the price.
2006 bottle poured into a Sam Adams Sensory Glass produced a thick tan head and dark brown body.  Fruity and spicey and sweetness monopolize the flavorfulness of this ale.

11.2 oz bottle purchased in WI.  Aroma is choclate with hints of earthy notes.  Beer pours a beautiful dark brown with an espresso collored head.  The flavors are impressive including roasty malts, nutty, and the sour apple flavor combined.  The beer is complex and is definitely a 10% ABV.  I feel there is quite a bit of carbonation but not too much to distract from the overall impression from the beer.  Great product.

Pours a lovely dark brown with a big fluffy head that doesnt last long.

Nose smells is sweetly alcoholic at first, chocolate and dark fruits an which then give way to sharper barnyard like herbal and wood aromas maybe apples too.

Taste is amazing, strong but not overpowering alcholic warmth, deep roasted fruit flavours, spices, a touch of lambic like sourness.

Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy but carbonated enough that this is very pleasant.

One of the best beers I have ever consumed.

Small 330 ml bottle (2007) from Cracked Kettle. Simply beautiful appearance: dark brown with a beige, large bubbly head leaving a small. steady espresso head as it quite rapidly dissipates. Definitely some milk chocolate in the aroma but also some sourness, apples and some strong notes of herbs, nuts, figs and an undertone of alcohol. Roasted, sweet malts and coffee are strong in the flavor as well as nuts, some mild sourness (apples) and spices. A  subtle burn of alcohol and a lovely dry, roasted maltiness in the aftertaste. Quite full yet well-carbonated in the palate, actually the contrast is quite nice. Definitely a tasty beer, but to be honest, not as fantastic as I expected. Maybe Pannepot Reserva will fill my expectations fully.

(330ml 2007 bottle) Pours an opaque dark chocolate brown. Nice light brown bubbly head, there are always bubbles around as I drink this one. Nose is milk chocolate, dried figs, spices and cinnamon and maybe some sweet crackers. Very complex. Taste is slight sour dried fruits, unsweetened chocolate, very carbonated and creamy. Palette finish is the best part of this beer, its not too sweet but towards the end the alcohol is becoming more and more apparent and I think it is overcarbonated. A great Quad/Strong, but maybe just shy of a top 50 beer for me.

Shared bottle from 2007. Pours dark, dark brown with a minimal bubbly head. Strong aroma of herbs, spices, and roasted malt. Taste is complex and spicy with a nice blend of dark fruits and some heavy hitting overpowering alcohol. I think I tasted this a little too warm, and 11oz. does not go far split 3 ways. I enjoy what I had, so I will have to try this again soon!

Pours a very dark mahoganey color with a giant tan creme color head that persists. Looks great. Nose is muted nutty fudge, red grapes, malt vinegar, and dark brown sugar.  Taste is very subtle and elegant. Notes of artificial grape, baked brownies, molasses, jelly sweet rolls, faint smoke, bit of sour something, and tootiesie roll.  Medium thick mouthfeel with some bubbles and a long haunting finish. This is the definition of old world beer. Well done.
Nice dark tasteful colour, dark herbal smell.  Strong fruity taste, spicy after.  Really deserves its high ratings.

Bottle pours deep purple with thin quick disapating tan head. Aroma is dark fruits and a little alcohol. First taste is sweet dark fruits then a little alcohol burn. The alcohol is well hidden with the aging and deep flavors.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2009 Bottle, 2007 Vintage. Simply amazing beer! Ive sampled this one several times and finally got around to rating it. Beautiful nose of plums, licorice and spice Taste of port, figs,raisins and spice. Finish very smooth.  Love it.

Finally found one 2007 vintage:  Poured dark brown and smelled wonderful of sweet toasty malts with some spice.  Flavor was sweet but not cloying and spice and fruity (raisans).  Very very pleasant and enjoyfully alcoholic.

This flavour is so deep. Its sour, yet sweet. It tingles the tongue and it tastes heavy of alcohol, nevertheless it pours away very very very well and quickly. Easily one of the best beers known to mankind.

330ml bottle. 2007 vontage. Pours dark black with a big foamy head that leaves great lacings. Head is brown and very foamy. Goergous look. Nose is nutty and spicy. Some chocolate and alcohol also. Notes of roasted malt. Warm alcohol feeling. Very powerful nose. Carbonation is soft. Taste is nutty and spicy as well. Quite sweet with notes of raisins and dark fruits. Notes of cherry also. Taste got much better with time. Small layer of foam stayed until the end.

2007 vintage. 11.2oz brown bottle served in a Chimay chalice. Bottle conditioned. Opened with a big pop. Tons of carbonation, I could only pour half into the glass. Poured a deep copper/mahogany with a lot of big bubbled tan head. Big aroma with lots of dark fruit, spice and some sugar. Very spritzy mouthfeel with all the carbonation. Medium bodied. More spice in the flavor, both the typical yeasty spice and added spice. Seems like there is a fair amount of hops, but that could be the spicieness. There is some dark sugar sweetness in the middle. Long dry finish. This is a nice beer. Very complex.
Bottle share with Jarspag. Thanks again. This was a great beer. Nice spice flavor, with a dark pour and nice head. Plums, raisins, figs, heavy carbonation. Very complex and enjoyable.

11.2oz bottle from 2007 stock.  Pours a deep brown with reddish tint when held up to light.  Capped off by a light tan head with bubbles of varying sizes that clings fairly well despite its short life.

Nose is figs, grapes, and booze, tipped off with a Christmas-y spice like nutmeg.  Flavor is also very sweet, with lots of figs and black cherries, thick caramel sweetness layered under sharp raw sugar sweetness.  The nutmeg-like spice is accompanied by others than I cant place, but they help balance the sweetness.

The alcohol hides fairly well, but comes through in the finish as the beer warms.  A bit of a lingering aftertaste, but still pleasant.

On tap at Lions Pride in Brunswick.
I knew this beer was popular, but wow, look at these ratings!!!  The pour is a nice dark brown with a good light tan maybe white head.  Aroma is figs and dates with sweet spices.  Flavor is nice, raisins, figs, slightly sweet brown sugar.  I got no boozey hints on this one, although it does pack a good punch. This is a really nice beer, is it the best?  Id say some of the ratings have been a little generous, but it is still exceptional.
It has been a couple of weeks since I drank this beer, but it is great.  Sorry I cant really relay more information.

aroma is strong of licorice and also sweet and well developed roasted malt. appearance is black as night with filthy head. flavor is of more licorice, also sweet spices such as clove, cinnamon and also stone fruits. its quickly easy to see why this is so renowned.  no booze in sight, if anything its a bit to sweet.  i dont say that as a criticism, only relevant because i detect that might be the body the alcohol has taken.  world class beer no question.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2011 Re-rate. 2007 bottle. Smells spectacular! Caramel, sour cherries, amazing spices, plum and brown sugar for aroma. Man, was I wrong on this beer before. Some sourness and the same qualities as the aroma. Did this on the last sip of beer. Another bottle or more will be purchased. 


Well.... if this isnt overpriced, what is? Poured out a quick death bubbly head and a solid dark brown brew. The aroma is eluding me as this lacks strength. Quite sweet, spicy with something that bites my nose like a cleaning product would - now Im not saying this smells like cleaning products so take it easy. Faint cinnamon, cherries, the dullest hint of smoke I think, molasses.... not too much else that I can notice and Ill admit that Im not in the mood to search and search for it tonight. The taste is thick, a mouth full of malts that remind me of bogs (no relation to taste), lots of spice, I just got a mouth full of yum yeasty sludge, sweet caramel, more cinnamon, figs or something, man, Im quite trashed, ginger? nutmeg. The mouth feel is thick and bordering on oily. The aftertaste is short lived but spicy with some alcohol and malts. Ill be forgoing spending money on this again. Maybe Im crapping on it because of the price but I dont think so. Good drink though, very easy to put back - just boring and quite honestly very forgettable.

33cl bottle. Pours a opaque deep brown body with thin creamy tan head. Some sediments too. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and a hint of alcohol. Very rich and complex flavor of spices, yeast, dried fruits, licorice and rum. Finishes with a little bitterness and roasted malt. The alcohol is well hidden. Palate is full with medium carbonation. Very well balanced, a pleasure to drink.
Bottle @ Ölbutikken. DArk brown with white head. Sweet maltiness fruity alkohol figs dates plum milkchocolate raisins spicy.

07 bottle.  Pour is deep murky brown with smallish tan head.  Some floaties in there too.  The whole room smells like this beer after the pour.  Banana, brown sugar, dates, dried plums, clove, cinnamon, light roasted malt, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is just enormous and oh so rich.  Brown sugar, dried fruits, banana, cinnamon, dates, caramel, and a touch of alcohol.  Alcohol was fairly well hidden.  This beer has outrageous complexity and richness.  It is so rich yet so drinkable, I love it.  I also love that huge aroma that filled my kitchen for minutes after the pour.  Will always have a few of these around from now on.

06 bottle.  Pours a dark cloudy mahogany with clear edges, thin tan head that sticks around for entire drink, decent lacing.  Left a decent bit of sediment on glass until almost the end of glass, which I then poured in.  Aroma of lightly roasted malt, chocolate, slight coffee, caramel, and alcohol.  Flavor matches with the addition of a nice spice profile, yeast, and dried fruits.  Alcohol a little more up front than I was expecting, but it doesnt dominate the drink.  Extra sediment toward end gave a bit of a spicier flavor, which I think would have been even better to have for the entire glass.  Truly a nice complex brew that I would enjoy to have more often.

11.2oz bottle from 2007. Pours a deep mahogany brown body with bits of sediment. Very creamy, inch thick, dense, dark tan head that dissipates very slowly, never completely disappears, and leaves some thick, layered lacing. Gorgeous. Aroma is sweet with lots of deep caramels. Raisin bread, dried fruits, chocolate and cream, a touch of roast, brown sugar, and a hint of licorice spiced booze. Flavor is quite sweet as well. Lots of caramels, nuts, dates, fruitcake, chocolate, plums, and a sweet booze. A light spicing keeps this very well balanced and enhances the layers of flavor. Finishes sweet with a touch of bitterness and a light roast. Palate is full and creamy with a good amount of carbonation. Slightly dry with plenty of aftertaste. Overall, a fantastic beer. Sweet, rich, balanced, and complex. World class.

bottle, dark dark brown colour with beige head. (wonderfull!). Smell: caramel, coffee and sugary. Taste: very complex,caramel, sugar, coffee, rhum, dried fruit, raisins and dried plums, very balanced sweetness, malty, creamy, alcohol, a bit sharpness and bitterness, yeasty. This is a real masterpiece. I really like this one.

Bottle 2007  Pours a dark brown with a good tan head.  The head is fizzy and lasting.   Produces good lacing.  Aroma is of sweet fruits, oak, and touches of vanilla.  Has a good carbonation.  Has a slight but good alcohol burn, very mild but a nice touch.  The flavor is well balanced.  The tastes dance on your tongue like subdued pop rocks.  Hasa slick texture.  A real good mouthfeel.  A solid finish with a good aftertaste.  This is just a darn good beer.

bottle 2007. pours a dark liquid with yeast particles and small creamy head. very complex with dark chocolate roasted coffee bean aroma. tastes sweet bitter. All of this well balanced and still very drinkable. excellent

33cl bottle, 07, PNP4
pours dark brown, light caramel head with nice golden lacing.
Aroma candy sugar, bready, coffee, some hints of possible vanilla sweetness, malty and dry fruits.
Taste, sweet dark malts, profile has some nice touch of candy sugar, some spices, bready, hints of coffee.
Some dry fruits; raisins and figs. Candy sugar leaves a thin sticky moutheel, as the beer warms up the palate becomes more caramel and spicy with what could be some cinnamon.

Pours extremely dark brown (in bad lighting) with a 1 1/2 finger beige fizzy head that has quite a bit of lasting power.  Poured straight from the cooler, theres a lot of alcohol, plum, and raisin.  Some sticky brown sugar sweetness comes out as it warms.  Fruit lightens to strawberries as it warms.  The flavor is extremely complex.  A strong bitterness with raisin and strawberry fruitiness.  Tons of warming alcohol.  There is a very roasty character to it as well, despite the fruit.  A really nice rich body that is enhanced by the tight carbonation. Very dry finish.  Excellent.

Bottle into snifter.  2007 vintage.  Muddy brown with fast fading head, no lace. Doesn;t look to special.  Smells really nice: fruity, oaky, vanilla, belgian candi sugar, malty, spicy, good.  Flavor is... a bit muddled upfront.  Lots going on (maybe too much for me).  Dark sweet fruit upfont (dates, dark grapes, prunes), whcih is complimented immediately by Balgian candi sugar.  Then comes the chocolatey, almost stoutish flavor with a warm and spicy burning alcohol finish.  Warming on the stomach.  Lots of good flavors, but a bit too aggressive and a bit too much going on IMO. Typical of the style, this is very highly carbonated, which detracts from flavor profile for me - really fizzy carbonation is just too distracting for me.  Overall: a fine beer, good even, but NOT a top 50 IMO.

THOUGHTS: I was looking for this for months. It was great. A little Mikeller Santas Little Helper 2007 and Rochefort 10, but more intense than either. There was so much going on, it is very hard to describe. It hid the alcohol fairly well. If it would have laced a little better I would have given it a perfect rating.
TECHNICAL: 2007 Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was almost black in the glass with reddish orange highlights when held to the light and a small to average, fizzy, tan head that kept a nice sheet for a very long time and left just barely fair lacing.
