user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle. Creamy, sweet and smooth. You wonder as this slides down your throat how it could possibly be 10%. All sorts of stuff going on, reminds me of me mums brandy cream with xmas pudding.

Bottle, courtesy after4ever. Pours a muddy dark amber with a thick, fluffy yellow head. Aromas of fruit, yeast. Creamy body with mild carbonation. Sweet taste of fruits, vanilla, nuts, caramel. Clean dry finish.

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur très complexe. On dénote, entre autre, des épices et des petits fruits sechés. Apparence: La couleur est brune foncée opaque avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col beige mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût très complexe. On dénote, entre autre, de la melasse, du caramel et de la cassonade. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture sirupeuse. Forte effervescence en bouche. Présence dalcool chaleureux en arrière goût. (Rating #688)

Brown color with a moderate beige head. Hints of garnet when held to the light. Aromas of raspberries, licorice and a plethora of dark fruit. Heavy and nearly foreboding. Licorice has always been a less than pleasant love of mine, so perhaps that may play a part of my less than delight of this brew. Flavors licorice, star fruit and mild port. Complex yes, but not my type of flavor explosion.

AWESOME!! 
1st time I had this I met Carlo in Daisys In Brugge. I had it when I got home, Blinding beer. Fruits, nuts, Spicey all wrapped up in the blanket of a abt 12 style brew! 
Ive had a couple of others, one a Panneput? Slightly different.  The 2006 is nearly back to the same way.

CARLO RULES!!

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2014 Bottled.  2005 vintage - brewed at Caulier.  Thanks very much to Madsberg for this one at last years GBBF which Ive been saving for a rainy day!.  I admit I opened this quite nervously as it has a huge reputation, and some beers with huge reputations pass me by (cf Westy 8), and additionally I am meeting Carlo at LCRBM on Sunday and didnt want to face him having given a bad rating!  I poured the beer into my Delirium Tremens glass and watched in awe as the attractive blanket of off-white head sat atop the almost black beer, with a little brown yeasty puddle.  I sniffed the aroma - tons going on here - and gave the glass to my wife for first sips - as I often do.  She has been known to wince at beers of 9% or more, merely stating "God thats strong", but not this one.  "mmmm thats nice" she said "a real food beer, you want some cheese with that", but I rate without food so I sat back down and took in the aroma again.  As I said tons going on.  Wood, yeast, licquorice, Christmas cake, a little brandy, plums and cherries.  Time to drink methinks.  Again wonderfully full and very very tasty.  Candied peel, sugars, cinnamon, nutmeg, berries, well hidden alcohol, chocolate, licquorice and boozy soaked peaches.  A really beautiful beer.  A true sipper.  Almost perfect, but what is perfect?  Score 4.7Subsequent rating scored 4.3. Average becomes 4.5
Deep dark cherry red with an off-white head. Funky musty, very strong aroma. Semi sweet start that stated to get heavier.

2005 vintage, hazy dark brown hue, with some reddish highlights, and a rocky tan-colored head, leaving laces, sweet winey fruity nose of plums, dates, figs, raisins, with a nice spicy accents of nutmeg, cinnamon, licorice, cocoa,vanilla, sweet milk chocolate, hints of fruitcake and toffee, with some caramelized, toasted malts in the aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate with a sweet toasted and roasted malts character, with a good licorice accent, black bitter chocolate, cocoa hazelnut, hint of black coffee beans, with molasses, brown sugar, and a syrupy mouthfell, and fruity notes, leading towards a very sweet malty chocolatey, and a well hidden warmth alcoholic fruity finish.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2006 Vi ville lave en smagssammenligning af Pannepot vintage 2005 smagt op i mod Pannepøt 2006.
Smuk mørkbrun farve og et holdbart beigefarvet skum. Mums.
Pannepøtten er lidt lysere og her forsvinder skummet øjeblikkeligt.
Duft af lakrids, ristet malt, mørke tørrede frugter, alkohol og "kage".
"Pøtten" er mere skarp af alkohol, tung sødme og ingen lakrids.
Smager af rosin, svedsker, madeira og sød maltet.
"Pøtten" er sød og tung i det ikke nær så kompleks og jeg kom lige et øjeblik til at tænke Trappist?
Rund og fyldig i munden.
Denne karakterrække er udelukkende baseret på "Potten" og ikke "Pøtten"

Bottle from my SecretSanta.  Pours mahagony with a frohty and fizzy off-white head, somewhat lasting.  Aroma is caramel malt (nutty, biscuit), yeast (dough, earth), banana, citrus and perfumey alcohol.  Medium sweet caramel banana malt, earthy yeast, moderate acidic burning alcohol and hops, some sweetness in the background.  Medium bodied, fizzy and foamy, spicy and dry palate.

Robe brune très claire aux reflets rouges surmontée dune mousse beige très épaisse qui persiste. Arômes de cerise, dépices, dagrumes, de caramel et de café. Saveurs de caramel, de sucre, de vin et de chocolat.

Pre-GTMW tasting @ 1FastSTis place. 2005 vintage. Dark brown with off-white head, lasting cover. The aroma plums, caramel, dark candi sugar and licorice. The flavor is toffee, candi sugar, plum skins, and  apples. The mouthfeel is soft, smooth and creamy.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2006 Dark brown - lasting offwhite head. Powerfull + fullbodied. Licorice, malty, hoppy, sweet, some candy, dried fruits, spices. A very good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 Rating #200, a huge thanks goes to xproudfoot for this 2005 bottle which was an extra in a trade! Pours a dark reddish brown, almost opaque with a fluffy light-yellowish-tan head that has a nice lasting power. Nice champagne-like aroma...crisp, fuity, with some brown sugar, cherry, and rasin. The flavor holds some nice candied cherry elements along with a bit of oak, fig, and a pinch of toasty malt, cocoanut, and warming alcohol. Silky carbonated body, an absolute pleasure over the tounge with a balanced sweetness throuout giving way to a dry boozey-sweet finish. Overall, an amazing beer.

Light cola color, thick light tan head. Bottom of bottle so a little murky
MM. Yummy peach, bubblegum, sour plums, prunes, sweet orange rind, slightly roasty dry malt, cherry twizzlers, fig newton, Beach perfume, sugar, vinousness. 
Sweet coffee. Fruit juice. Subtle flavors that come together nicely, but Im looking for a little more after the aroma.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 A Mes rate: 33cl bottle from Staminee de Garre in Bruges.2005 Vintage.;)WOW, what a stunner this is. If it wasnt for it being just a little too sweet this would be truely fantastic. Nose has that wonderful aged note that I love so much. The liquorice and candy sugar show clearly throughout. It starts with the spice in the nose and finishes with it too. A wonderful encapsulation. Apparent also are apple and vanilla in what is a wonderfully complex aroma. Great length. Lots of dark fruit and malt in the flavour. Deep dark red/brown body with a fair amount of floaters in there topped with a rocky beige head that settles to a thick almost inpenetrable film. Alcohol is just a pleasant undercurrent, quite a feat considering its obvious strength. Complex and well rounded but the dominating character is the candy sugar, liquorice and a lovely note of ginger. A chunky and full bodied gem. The last pour made it virtually black due to the sediment. Ohh coffee and pepper in the flavour too. It just keeps on giving up more. You can tell by my rate that this is one of those beers that sends you all over the place. Stunning stuff. Best new try for me in a long long time. It has it all, balance, body, complexity la la la la la. Get some now!

Hazy, murky ruby and dirty caramel brown with a foamy, dark tan head retaining like nobodys business.  Aroma, in a word, is "intense."  In another word? "Beauty."  Dates, black cherry pits and English pipe tobacco interweave with spruce.  It keeps coming - caramelized sugar to a burgundy beat, prunes marinating in a plum brandy sauce... the dark fruited list is endless.  Needless to say, originality has found its spokesperson.  Flavor is admirably divine.  Plums and caramelized dates hit the taste bud receptors and heart strings simultaneously first.  Rum raisins dive into saucy mince meat pie.  Figs bob and weave and plummet into a fishermans bowl of brandied, caramelized raisins.  Consecutive sipping and savoring produces a dark fruited nirvana, pulling on moderately dry tobacco and corresponding cigar wrappers, and melding with rustic black cherry skin, flambéed fig juice and a dainty yet healthy dose of ever-warmed concord sauce spiced with nutmeg and spread over prunes.  Boisterous blackberries interweave with said flavors to create a fairly full-bodied complex.  Twining caramel-laden plum sauce sings sweetly into the night with a mild, earthen dry tobacco character.  Simply incredible.  Thanks to JCapriotti and MrFacto for bringing bottles, and Chuck for pouring the rest of his allotment into my mouth when he was done rating!

Almost black colored with some red hints. Little beige head. Caramel and excellent vinous tones in rich aroma, also licorice and and warming alcohol can be found. Almost full bodied. Flavor is unbeliavable: licorice, caramel, port-wine, medium alcohol, some berries and fine hoppy dryness. Aftertaste lasts with crispy alcohol and licorice. Excellent full bodied beer.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2007 2005 vintage Thanks Jason and Matt.  The beer pours to a very dark garnet body.  Nice tan head.  The aroma is dark fruits, sweet nutmeg, walnuts, and yeast.  The flavor is walnuts, sweet dark pitted fruits.  The palate is a little watery, medium-light body. 9, 5, 8, 3, 16 = 4.1

2006 vintage The beer pours to a really dark black/brown body with ruby highlights.  A dark tan head sits on top.  The aroma is very complex and full of spices.  Nutmeg, mace, cinnamon, chocolate, dates, walnuts, and yeast.  The flavor is much the same as the aroma.  Very complex.  As the beer decanted, it changed for the better.  Wow!  What a delight with this one.  The palate is heavy, spicy, full bodied.  Much better than the 2005 vintage.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2008 Pre-Great Taste sampling at 1FastStis house

There were two 2005 vintage bottles of this opened.  I got the bottom of the 
   first one for an extra special yeasty treat.  At some point it would be nice
   to try it again with a better sample simply to see how it compares.  It was
   well made, but at least to me it falls just short of what I would consider a
   Top 50 beer.
Aroma / Appearance - The half-finger tan head lingered over top of a
   midnight brown body.  My pour was a little darker than the others; I think
   I got the dregs of the bottle in mine, causing it to be cloudy and murky.
   The complex nose had hints of fresh honey, caramelized sugar, bittersweet
   bakers chocolate, peppers and cloves.  It balanced well - nothing seemed
   out of place but at the same time I felt it could have been maybe a little
   more dense.
Flavor / Palate - Green apples, cloves, freshly squeezed honey,
   caramel, black cherries and both bittersweet and bakers chocolate.  The
   mouthfeel was well balanced and smooth.  I felt as if it could have possessed
   some more texture.  The finish was a little lacking as well - despite a
   pleasing dry coffee feel I was left wanting more.  If the finish were better,
   this would be borderline Top 50.

Thanks to Jason & Matt for sharing.
Deep red hughes gigantic thick creamy ultra firm well laced head w/ visable carbonation.  Huge aroma very big and spicy.  Tons of dark fruits, figs, toffee, touches of nuts and lots of sweetness.  Palate is creamy but a bit thin in body, light and fluffy mouth feel.  Flavor is dark fruits plum/fig light toffee some butter an odd off spice that isnt really appealing.  Flavor is a bit of a letdown.

Aroma is very strong, with lots of dried figs, wild berries and tons of caramel malt with a touch of smoke. Dark, mostly opaque mahogany brown with a thin, off-white head.  Sweet flavor that is loaded with complex malty flavors that include chocolate, dried fruit, licorice, caramel and cigar smoke.  Murky and complex.  Medium-full body and very creamy.  Thanks to the person brought and shared this!
My last belgian beer in belgium and if i had my way the last one ever.  dark color and one of those sweet bsas like abaye des rocs brun or whatever.
24/05/05. Brugges.  Deep dark cherry red with an off-white head. Funky musty aroma. Semi sweet start that stated to get heavier. Quite enjoyed this drop.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2007 the american release of this isnt so hot
****
Pretty good stuff.  Pours a chestnut brown with a small head.  Aroma is intense spice and fruit.  Flavor is the same with a bit of alcohol and much more sweetness than I expected.  Mouthfeel isnt as heavy as I expected...or compared to similar brews.  Very well balanced and quite a big beer in its own respects.

Bottled. Clear brown beer with a reddish note. The head is small, creamy and beige, and it lasts for a while. Complex aroma with tobacco, sugar, dried fruits and spices. The alcohol is surprisingly missing. Quite sweet, but indeed pleasant flavor with brown sugar, tobacco, dried fruits, grapes and raisins. Creamy and sweet in the mouth. A beautiful beer I really loved to taste again, and hope to repeat. (060714)

Bottle:  Shared by the artist formerly known as wolhfs.  I also received one in a trade with Phillip, but unfortunately I dropped that one and it broke.  Excellent aroma of dark fruits, yeast, moderate chocolate, licorice, and a hint of alcohol.  Pours a dark brown with some orange tine and a small beige head.  Lots of dark fruit, residual sugar, chocolate, toffee, and raisin.  Flavors really blend well together and incredibley smooth for 10%.  Alcohol is barely noticeable.  Outstanding!

Thanks to sk8viking for this beer.
This pours an opaque dark brown with a large head that stays around for a while. The flavors are very complex: apples: cinnamon, chocolate, raisns and a few other goodies. Tasty.

05 vintage from a 33cl bottle, no government warning on the label, nice! Bottle acquired in a recent trade with Eyedrinkale. Large tan head, excellent retention, laceing is minimal, stringy at times spotty at others. Chestnut brown color, hazy with deep copper colored edging. Nose is rich, fruity apple notes with some coriander and chocolate, spicey. Body is medium with a surprisingly gentle carbonation, a touch oily. Nice. A blend of fruit flavors, orange, apples, raisins meld nicely with the chocolate and caramel flavors, the spices hanging around. A hint of licorice, bready malts and toffee making themselves known. 10% alcohol is nowhere to be found, amazing! Finish is lightly sweet and fruity. A real treat indeed. Thanks Mike! You da f* -->n man!
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2007 bottle. murky deep brown color. malty and spicy. very sweet but also complex. taste last for quite a while.

2005 bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, Harrys bottle.  Milky hazy brown, bib bubbly brown head. Malt, spice, light chocolate flakes, and sourness in aroma - really really nice and unique.  Wow, incredible taste:  tons of sweet chocolate, malt, slight spice - alcohol is barely present.  Fruity finish.  Complex and unique, my description has not done it justice.  I loved it and it exceeded expectations.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Vintage 2005.</i > Pours a murky dark brown with floaties and a huge lasting rocky off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, chocolate, spices, a mild sourness, brown sugar, dark fruit and more -- nice and complex. Flavour follows the aroma and is quite sweet but never cloying, very well balanced and once again, complex. Alcohols well hidden. Full bodied. This is simply fantastic.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2006 Bottle (330ml).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle via trade with Boutip.  Poured thick opaque deep reddish-brown with a large lasting tan foamy-creamy head, plenty of white chunkies.  Rich caramel malt, rich spices, brown sugar, very yeasty, chocolate toffees, tart treefruits and a double hint of red wine and lactose; boozy on warming.  Taste as the aroma, more alcohol and chocolate, still plenty of malt, quite bitter on the finish, lovely, strong, sweet yet balanced.  Mouthfeel thick, syrupy, mildly alcoholic, complex and wonderful.  I wish it had been a 75cl bottle.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 800th rating. Thanks to xproudfoot for this one. 2005 bottle. Wow! Poured a cloudy deep brown body with a huge head and excellent lacing. Aroma is spices (big time anise), dark sugar, dark fruits, chocolate, caramel, yeast, more.. wow. Flavor is just so smooth. I couldnt ask for better balance here. 10% ABV is nowhere to be seen. Complex, balanced, tasty, smooth... truly a great beer.

375 ml 2005 bottle special thanks to xproudfoot.  Pours a murky brown with a wonderful tan head.  Aromas were a lot of molassas, caramel, brownsugar, raisin, anise, dark cherry, and toffee.  More of the same in the flavor.  Sweeter than the aroma though.  Sugar cubes, and some alcohol, but not a lot.  I just couldnt find anything about this beer I didnt like.

Bieropholie Private import. 2005: Dark brown ale with little floaties. Thick resilient moka head. Agreeing with colleagues below, this is definitely has a very nice berry aroma, blueberry, with notes of licorice and caramel. In mouth, a nice sweet blueberry, candi sugar  and licorice, with smooth alcohol lasting, and   lighter bodied than expected. However, this is a teaser and a pleaser.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2006 Courtesy of MrWalker
<!-- P -->
2005 Bottle
<!-- P -->
Aroma is full of fresh blueberries/blackberries I mean HUGELY full of it. Its like sticking your nose in a bush. A berry bush ya perv! Also get lots of black licorice, sweet bread dipped in molasses and some spicy alcohol. Body is a murky brown with a magnificent creamy tan head that is a full two fingers thick, extra fluffy and long lasting. Fore is sweet candi sugar, molasses, bready sweet malts, mashed berries, perfumey alcohol. Very desert like and could be cloying if I wasnt in the mood for it. Still its a lovely beer and a real treat.

Bottle (vintage 2005): Poured opaque dark brown ale with a super huge foamy dirty brown head with perfect retention. Aroma of liquorice and sweet malt is incredibly well balance. Taste is an almost perfect balance between strong sweet malt with caramel and liquorice with some candi sugar (I would say a bit too much though) with a slightly funky ending from the yeast. Body is full and alcohol is very well masked. This beer is almost like a sweeter version of Rochefort 10 and there is not much more praise I can give to this beer.

Truly great beer enjoyed from the bottle at De Garre.  A very deep beer layered with a great amount of flavors, each in harmony even at their most dissonant.  The first sensation is darkness with gingerbread and molasses.  This lends a good balance of savory spice and sweetness.  Further back on the tongue are notes of licorice and wood (cedar?).  The brew finishes like strong, bitter coffee.  If this is what Old Fishermen drink, I want to know how to get that job.

Vintage 2005...
Aroma:full of liquorice,dark fruit....
Appearance:Dark brown,huge tan head...
Flavor:Liquorice all the way,sugar,Toffe.....
Murky brown pour with a short tan head. Chocolate cake and icing sugar aroma. Citrus, coffee, chocolate and toffee resonate throughout. Quite nice.

Beautifull poored out with a brown to dark robin red colour. large creamy off white head. Some sweet caramel aroma, with some coffee and toffee hints, light fruity as well. Full fruity taste, some caramel. Finish is alcoholic, creamy with again a bitter-sweet caramel ending. Very nice balanced beer, this is a top one.

Rating#1300 - 33cl bottle 2005 vintage via trade with Philip and Duane!  - Thanks guys! - Poured dark brown with an amazing fluffy tan head that stayed amazingly well and laced the sides of the tulip in layers.  Aroma is yeast, raisins, smoky malts, caramle, and candi sugar.  Flavor is yeasty, with much raisin presence.  Smoky roasted malts and caramel richness are solid contributers in the background too.  Some hops on the finish but this is mostly malty.  Quite complex and the flavor almost seems to change sip by sip.  Palate is soft smooth and airy.  Definitely a fine ale and one to seek out!  Thankful to have a chance to try this one!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2006 33 cL bottle, 2005 on the label: dark reddish purple body with a persistent, light tan fluffthe aroma is wonderfully and amazingly complex: zesty, fruity yeast, vanilla beans, oak and soft tannins.  Bittersweet raisins dusted with Bakers chocolate dust.  Sweet and ripe, lightly tart plums.  Dark red grape jelly and complex yeast roll over the tongue a top a lightly tingly carbonation.  Clean finish that leaves sticky, fruit flesh throughout the mouth.  Simply outrageous!  WOW.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2006 [Bottled. 2005.  Big thanks to joergen]
Dark brown. Huge creamy off-white head. The aroma is enormous, mostly tidbits but also licorice, higher alcohols and a touch of citrus. The body is pretty light at this abv-level. Tidbits, rubber dominates the flavour. Loads of fruits here. Lingering finish.

Truly a nice beer. Very dark brown with limited brown head. Aroma is mostly sugary and caramel. It starts with smoky flavours that expands to malty sweetness and a touch of bitterness. Doesnt feel vinious at any point.

This dark brown ale poured with a nice tan head, eliciting a malty aroma. The flavor is marvelously complex with a predominance of chocolate malt, but otherwise quite balanced. The alcohol is well-masked, and the flavor just keeps getting better as the glass empties.

Huge light brown head, that took forever to dissapate. Nice medium brown color with medium soft mouth feel.
Sweet carmely taste with hints of livorice and fruit. Alcohol not too noticeable. Like drinking a lighter version of one of the good quadrupels. Very good.

Bottle 2005 TY Papsoe.A beauty: brownfizzy dirty ivoty, slanted muff hat head.  Big Brown Beear.  The head GROWS! When I look away - over several minutes of a programme, when I turn back it has expanded to twice its size; a tufty willow and cotton freshba ball on the top - the beer is a natural phenomenon! Whoa.Aroma is delightful: big oak cake and vanilla raisin warm hearthHave to taste the head first as its so largein the big Duvel glass.   This appetizer is a bit like bitter tree bark.The beer itself is a delight: cognac plum, delicious perfumed sweethops briar. Vanilla, choco, and wood.  Excellent. Definitely a near relative of my former favorite beer, though this is that extra mile beyond that excellent brew.  Thanks very much to my Danish friend. This, the motivation for our trade, was worth every bit of work.

Average of 2 ratings:
2004: Kinda ambery pour, a bit hazy but decanted.  Intense and delightful aroma of caramel malts and nice fruits, and some interesting spices.  Malty fruity flavors - caramel and toffee and medium fruits and some plums too.  Warming and delicious.
2005.  Bottle, hazy brown pour.  Malty and fruity, but not as complex or wow as the 2004.  Body was not quite the same either, although it seemed a fair bit sweeter.  This was a let-down when drunk side-by-side with the 04.

Bottle. Off-white creamy and long lasting head. Dark red unclear body. Complex spicy and yet fruity and just a bit alcohol aroma. Thick fluidum giving a nice creamy  mouthfeel. Plum liquorice flavor and a pleasant sweetness. I would not have guessed that it had such a high alcohol percentage.

12 oz bottle, 2005 vintage, via sk8viking.  Pours a deep rusty brown with a fluffy billowy off-white head two fingers in height.  Lots of visible carbonation.  Glass almost completely coated with sticky lacing.  Nice spicy and fruity aroma, gingersnap cookies, licorice, candied plums, belgian yeast, and orange rind combine for a rather complex nose.  Flavor is very sweet with dark fruits, spices, caramel, toffee, and light yeast.  Some alcohol, but very well hidden at 10%, coming out in the finish with licorice and candi sugar.  Medium bodied with high carbonation that foams slightly in the mouth and leaves behind a slightly sticky and cloying finish.  A very nice complex Belgian, on par almost with a Rochefort 10 in the sense of flavor complexity.  Worth seeking out, Id probably buy alot of this were it to become available in the US.

2005 Vintage provided by my main man Mads Berg and served in a Duval Snifter:  Poured a rich mahogany hue topped by a huge fluffy head and excellent lace. The aroma is a interesting combination of crab apple, prune, starfruit, candi sugar, caramelized malt, earthy yeast esters, hint of smoke and wood. Nice and inviting indeed.  The taste is very fruity and very sweet, almost too much sugars left about. Some oaky and ashy subtones added depth before a mild smack of anise and herbal notes. The aftertaste is vanilla, nutty and vinous character. The mouth feel is a tad chalky and underwhelming for all this presented on the palate.  While this is a good beer, I hardly found it Top 50 worthy. The sweetness needs something else to counter and excite the palate more often. I would like the chance to try it again under different conditions.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2007 2004 Vintage: Poured a hazy amber color with an off white head.  The aroma is sweet, malty and fruity.  Caramel and apples in the flavor.  Only missing the stick to hold it.  Finish was semi-dry with a fizzy mouthfeel and very warming.  The finish had licorice and some spice.  it reminded me of the licorice candy  that came in the little packets and were tiny little flecks.   2005 Vinatge:   This was far less complex.  A good bit sweeter and a fair amount of bitterness.  Pretty hot alcohol as well.2006 Vintage: Poured a hazy brown color with a tan head.  the aroma was spiced and yeasty with a sweet malt base.  Notes of cinammon, ginger and bread.  Malty flavor with some fruity notes.  Light alcohol.  Lively mouthfeel. 8/3/8/3/15

UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 Numbers are the consolidation of my thoughts of 04 and 05 vintages.

04 - Pours heavily carbonated, with aroma that sneaks throughout each bubble. The spices come first, then the winter aromas of fruit cake and egg nogg appear. St. Nick would be so lucky to find this awaiting his arrival. The complexity is astonishing, with nearly every posssible facet being different. The thick and full palate remind one of its residual sweetness, but the gingerbread never overtakes the tawny port characteristic. From start to finish - a masterpiece.

05- An entirely different beer. Aroma of vanilla and flavor of cherry predominate. The body seems more thin and the alcohol burn is substantial. Still an excellent beer, almost to the level and style of St. Bernardus 12.

I can see the validity of the mixed reviews here. I cannot see anyone that likes/loves Belgian Strong Ales having a distaste for the divinity of the 04 bottle I had.

Nice deep mahogany color...big fluffy tannish head.  Big aroma...sweet malts, caramel and toffee, very roasty yet spicy too.  A lot is going on with this one.   Mouthfeel is very silky smooth...choco-malts, sweet but not overly so.  Spiciness is maintained, raisins, port, molasses, with a big carbonated fizz.  Wow....its hard to gather this one in.  Alcohol is big the entire way.  What a great brew!

33 cl bottle. Dark brown colour with a great head. Wonderfull aroma of sweetness, malt but in a complex way, ends up in your nose, just like a good Port-wine. Great sweet flavour with notes of dried fruit, malt nearly like liquid candy.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2006 Bottled, 2005 vintage, brewed at Caulier. Strong licorice aroma with anis and coreander. Dark brown color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, licorice, light spices, light bitter, soft, alcohol well hidden. Like liquid candy (in a good way).

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2006 A mostly lasting large rocky tan head tops up a medium brown body. Heavy lacing. No particles. Many big bubbles. Unfiltered. Aroma presents malt being moderate grain /wood/caramel while hops are very faint ... Yeast character is moderate fruitiness and gingerbread... Also, there are evident evocations of lavender and rosewater plus some notes of raisin. Initial flavor is moderate sweet while development shows some licorice and very light saltiness. Finish is medium and present red fruits overtones. Medium body... creamy texture... Soft but well suited carbonation... apparently this beer is quite unstable and we had an excellent bottle. Thanks MikeMac!

[ Bottled ; chilled ; dates are unknown ]

Pours with a dark reddish-brown body topped by a thick head with a good amount of lacing.  ITs sweet and fruity with a nice malt note, a little almond and a touch of licorice.  Medium bodied, smooth and dry.

Tried two bottles: 2005 and 2004 (at Kulminator). The 2005 was OK visually, but over-the-top sweetness killed it for me. Generally a rich beer with fruit and chocolate notes and enough sugar to kill a tooth. The 2004 was less sweet, but everything else was also less. Not complex and not particularly tasty. Is this the most over-rated beer here?

Thanks to Yogi_Beera for this one, #600 for me, poured with a huge tan head, and a ruby/brown color, first taste was of candy sugar to me, very sweet, but mellows as it warms, alcohol noticable, but not overpowering, overall a bit sweeter than I like, but it would be great on a snowy day, in front of a fire.

Dark brown colour with a tan head, dried fruit and carmel aroma; very sweet taswte with raisin and sugar aromas; sweet finish with more dates and raisin aromas.
Surely one of the most over-rated beers. Far too sweet and lacking  any great complexity. Not a patch on Rochefortoise Bruin, on which it is supposedly based. Where is the chocoalte flavour? Not a beer I would choose to drink orten - Gulden Draak is more complex and less cloying. Why do so many people think this beer is wonderful?

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 Giant head on a beer of mixed shades. A wizards glass of brown clouds. Aroma is licorice root, yeast, alcohol and an air of sweetness. Flavour is mostly salt water toffee, licorice flavoured. A novelty beer that will not stay in the top 50. (or so I thought)
Bottle at the Kulminator.  Poured a dark brown with a large head.  Had a caramely, malty aroma.  It definitely tasted sweet with a little spice to it.  Not too damn bad.

murky brownish red, almost auburn or chesnut in nature; aroma is very dopplebock-like, with chocolate, dark berries, caramel, nuts, vanilla, molasses and raison ...flavor is of chocolate, dark fruit, raison, and bread...nice and smooth...very TASTY!

2005 vintage.  Many thanks to Walt for this bottle.  Murky red-brown body, medium light tan head.  Big, doppelbocky aroma, with strong caramels, toast, toffee, raisin, and prune.  This reminded me of bread pudding.  Sweet, sugary body with heavy malts.  Raisin, prune, brown sugar, toffee, toast, and hints of chocolate made this a rich drinking experience.  Alcohol was toned down.  Complex and unique for the style.  The heavy sweetness, though not cloying, prevents an even higher rating.  Very good.

Deep, dark brown with ruby highlights. Lasting pillowy tan head. Tempting aroma of dark sugar, spices, chocolate, figs, raisins and caramel. Flaavour is sweet, yet not cloying. Some wonderful notes of prunes, choc, raisins, caramel, figs and light spice. Celebration in a bottle. Medium, silky smooth body. Such a well balanced, tasty beer. Top class, and very moreish.

Wow - this made me completely forget, the sleet and cold winds outside for the entire evening.
Gorgeous dark red body with lasting light tan head.
Lots of dark fruits (raisins, plums, ripe berries) in both aroma and taste. Quite sweet with clear taste of brown sugar, but not too sweet. I imagine the glass will last me pretty much the whole evening - partly because I can just sit down and enjoy the aroma.
I bet this would be lovely on its own as  a dessert after a nice meal.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2008 Bottle at RBESG Grand Tasting. Sorry Carlo, its just too sweet for my palate.  And I just have problems with sweet beers. Full stop. I love the full spicy, malty aroma. And the rich, plummy fruit on the palate. And the dark chocolate underbelly. Some vinous notes there too.  But I cant get away from the syrupy sweetness. Some rough bitter edges might provide some relief but its so damn smooth too. No doubting its a well put together beer but, ultimately, not really entirely to my taste yet. Im told the sweetness reduces with age so I guess Id better try to get some bottles to age. 8/4/6/3/14=3.5RE-RATE: Bottle, at de Garre, Brugge, April 2008 (2006 vintage). Bottle age makes a lot of difference. Still bags of raisin and prune fruit and big spices but the sweetness has receded to leave a truly luscious and succulent beer. Licorice on the finish. Very yummy (although Id probably still prefer something a little drier). Score updated.

Catching up my ratings, from 12/10/05 at Yeha thanks Dickinsonbeer and willblake and optimator for sharing this one.  Aroma of caramel and fruits,floral hops. Pour was a clouded swirling brown. Flavor was just a treat. Sweet and slightly spiced, caramel. It was great and a true honor to have.

A very well balanced yeasty-biscuit syrup decadently saturated with caramel-maple hints and and nicely alcoholic.  A sweet, rich mix of brown sugarand  pecans and raisins and figs and pomengranate and bread pudding and baklava.  Thick and satisfying, and now I want a bottle all to myself.

Tasted at a Danish beer enthusiasts club meeting. Tan frothy head on a dark red body. The aroma alone announces an exceptional brew, and the taste surely does not disappoint. It felt warm and inviting. Hints of fruits and chocolate, brown sugar, sweet yet bitter, it plays on all registers, like a symphony. Definitely one of the best I have experienced. Congratulation to BierKönig and his Ølbutik for tqking the initiqtive to i;port this excellent beer/

bottle courtesy of Philip.  great aroma of caramel and fruit.  slightly hazy dark brown in color with a tannish head and plenty of lace.  sweet caramel flavors with some ripe fruit and brown sugar.  quite good but flavors were not as complex as I expected.  very enjoyable brew, thanks again Phil

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2009 Another top fifty beer. Thanks for sharing, Duane. The dark red body had a medium tan colored head. The aroma was iced tea with peaches and ginger. There was also a definite chocolate note. The taste was initially sweet chocolate cake. There was also some toffee and mild Red Delicious apples. A very soft mouthfeel and the alcohol isnt detected. A solid beer. Sampled again from a 330 ml bottle of the US 2006 version. Still, a soild beer, but not extraordinary.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2007 [bottle from kulminator] the first beer i drank in kuminator bar. great aroma of ripe fruit, raisins, chocolate, figs, candy floss. big smooth body, i love this shit, Carlo is a legend!

12oz. bottle 2005 from The Bier Temple. Deep brown color, ivory head!Sweet aroma of caramel and fruit! Burnt sugars, prunes and some cookie dough out front with some bitterness and definite alcohol presence in the back! Yeah this is very nice!!

2005 bottle. Thanks to Walt for this one. Murky, dark brown pour with a loose tan head.  Sweet and smokey, heavy caramel and over ripe fruit aroma. Very sweet in flavor with coffee, caramel, some woodiness, some spiciness and some multi vitamin. Quite fortifying, if a bit sweet for my tastes. Reminds me of Midnight Sun M.

12.10.05  This bottle thanks to Dickinsonbeer at RLB YEHA-05, maybe my 4th time sampling it.  Messy brown pour is a bit murky and sits looking mostly still below a small brown head.  The aroma is doughy, biscuit, raisin bread, rocky road ice cream with fudge; its chocolate and ovaltine.  Absolutely gorgeous stuff, softly roasted, almond and praline, melted marshmallow and graham, vinous, integrated yeasty spice.  Like some other giant Belgians, this one delights the palate with more eff than youd expect, yet is still velvety smooth and chamois soft.  Beautifully fragrant throughout.  Im babbling.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 Rerate:  2006 vintage.  A gusher that I barely managed to get into my glass before it coated my entire kitchen.  Poured a murky brown with a small fizzy light tan head.  Aroma is spicy with notes of cinnamon, wheat bread, a bit of alcohol.  Flavor is both sweet and dry with notes of honey wheat bread, cinnamon, molasses, some floral essences, with a touch of metallic bitterness in the finish.  Body is light and sparkling, which was awfully refreshing.  Though with the almost gingerbread-like spiciness, I was hoping this would be a bit more viscous.  It certainly doesnt feel like a big beer... except when the alcohol hits.  Some really nice flavors and well balanced, though not everything Ive enjoyed in my absolute favorite Belgian strongs.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2007 Poured a darker and cloudy brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of dark fruits, yeast, caramel, light chocolate and brown sugar. Tastes of dark fruits, caramel and some chocolate. On the sweeter side (but not cloying). 8 4 8 4 17

Re-rate. Tasted this along side the Authentic version. This time around I also got a lot of spices in addition to the other mentioned aromas and tastes; ginger, spruce, and a bunch more. I liked the other version better and had to lower the scores on this one a bit.

2004 bottle, "Old Fishermans Ale".  Hazy off-brown with a fluffy, medium-dense head.  Some fruit and spice, but also marked by a musty edge perhaps and cocoa powder and lactic milk chocolate.  Good palate, very fluffy, though it made it hard to get ahold of it.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2009 (Bottle, courtesy of Walt)  Pours a dark brown body with a medium-sized foamy beige head.  Aroma of dark fruits, roasted malt, and cocoa.  Flavor of malt, dark fruits, chocolate, and spices.

Bottle. Grapey nose and taste, reminded me of Dr. Pepper syrup. Lots of rich dark fruits, dates, figs, etc. Good amount of sweetness. Secondary notes of gingerbread and dough. Not nearly as good as I was hoping.
Shared with SuIIy.  Decent head, good nose, very sweet and candy like.  I really enjoyed the taste, its very sweet wichi I like.

12oz bottle from Walt. Pours a Speckled brown color with a off white head. Lots of bubbles. Nose is very sweet, lots of sugars, caramel, some light sweet malt, raisins. Flavor is also very sweet, lots of burnt sugars, dark fruits, raisins, some light dough here and there. A very nice thick body that doesnt over do it. Notes of dark cherrys and licorice come to mind.

Brown/coloured, a little cloudy, sparkling with a thick and foamy head. Do I dare to drink it and spoil this beauty? Aroma is raisins/pruns, dark candi sugar and liqourice. Very smooth almost silky, taste. Great mouthfeel, thick and sweet, but not cloying. Liqurice and dark fruits dominates the flavour. It lives up to my expectations!

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2006 Bottle 2004 at Kulminator. After taking some recommendations from other RBers, this was the first beer I ordered here.  And what a drink.  Only my third 5/5.  Dark brown/chestnut colour with thick lasting beige head.  Dark fruits on the aromas, but quite a fresh creamy nose as well.  Beautifully soft in mouth, quite vinuous.  Amazing raspberry, black cherry and creamy fruit flavours.  Finish has some sourness and sweet fruit, both at the same time.  Some dark choc as well.  Wonderful.  This was built up in my expectations to be good and in fact it was even more stunning than I had anticipated.  A brilliant beer. 
Re-rate 2005 bottle De Garre.  This is as good as it gets.  Great vinous feel and flavours.  Wonderful and great great fruit. 5/5

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 Bottle, 2005, courtsy of MullMan. Pours cloudy brown, with a medium light brown head. Aromas are dark fruit, spices, licorice, gingerbread, sweet malt, and some chocolate. Flavors are sweet malt, dark fruit, spices, licorice, dark bread and/or gingerbread, and even bits of chocolate and sherry. What an amazing brew.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2007 Bottle, vintage 2005. Beautiful brown/red colour. The licorice in the aroma is absolutely amazing! Sniffing this beer is an addiction in itself! I find my nose dripping with beer whenever I have Pannepot. But the fun doesn´t stop there! The taste is a fantastic malt and licorice explosion with chocolate undertones, which together with a rather high carbonation, creates a beer unlike any other! If they serve beer in Paradise, this must be one of them! But why is my bottle already empty?

2006 US version: Dark with a huge brown head. Aroma of spices, licorice, malt, brown sugar and yeast. Sweet flavour with notes of licorice, brown sugar and caramel. Delicious! 8-4-9-4-18

[RBG Low Countries 2005] Finally i found some time to continue my ratings from the beermeeting in the Kulminator. :D Starting with this exceptionally interesting brew. It has a chocolate malty, bit licorice-like aroma. Very strong and pleasant some madeira/port like notes. Hazy, brown almost black coloured with an off-white, lasting medium head. Very full taste (good body!). Sweet, chocolate and caramel malty, some licorice. Slightly sticky. So delicious.

Bottle 2005 Thanks, Jeppe (BierKönig) for bringing me this one.It has a big creamy head. Unique aroma! Have never come about this kind in my 20 years of beer hunting. It feels right, though. Sort of sourness from an oud bruin, wine like, sweet stout, brownies, figs & plums and more. In taste, the first that hits you is the sweetness, then a breadlike short period, red wine hits in, caramel, warming alcohol. Hard fudge and caramel in aftertaste. A very nice beer but too sweet for me. It would improve with a few years in the cellar.

Thanks to Phil (pdhabel) for providing this.  Pours a rich mahogany with a big tan head that provided beautiful lacing.  Lots of tiny bubbles rising in the glass.  The aroma was sweet, some berries, sherry, spice cake, raisins.  Lots of fun there.  Full bodied, smooth and creamy, with gentle carbonation.  The flavor was a pleasing presentation of the aromas to the palate.  Smooth, sweet, vinous, spicy.  A Belgian that I enjoyed.

Rating 100. Many thanks to Carlo for providing this one as my friends traveled through Belgium. A great person, and a great brewer. Regarding the beer, lots of things going on. Spices such as ginger and nutmeg/mace come through on the nose and again on the palate. A sweetness here that makes me think this is best enjoyed with a fine cigar. Very malted and well-rounded. Im looking forward to ageing a few bottles, and sharing a few with others who need to taste this fine beer. Thanks again, Carlo! A fitting way to celebrate a ratebeer milestone.

Great aroma with a complex mix of  liquorice, gingerbread and fruit. Dark brown with a big and lasting beige creamy head. Flavour is very sweet, chocolate predominates, developing to more refreshing and long-lasting fruitiness towards the end. Unbalanced, but delicious!

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2011 2010-07-31, vintage 2005, 5 years old, 8-5-8-4-16=41The color is a very dark amber, clean, with generous and creamy head. The aroma shows some oxidization, more than the flavor though; its malty, sweet; the bitterness is all gone. Still good, but probably at its limit.2009-05-27, vintage 2005, 4 years old, 8-5-8-4-17=42Dark color, almost black; the head, initially medium sized, reduces ot a thin but persistent layer. Good aroma, very mature, with some caramel and chocolate. It has a good body, with caramel and malt flavor, medium sweet, liquor-like, with tobacco leaves; mature, but also a bit fruity, harmonious and complex at the same time. The alcohol feeling is more evident. It has almost no bitterness. Very interesting, but I think it may be even more in 5 or 6 years.2005-20-21, 8-5-9-4-17=43Cloudy brown color. Very nice aroma, some Madeira, Porto wine. Sweet, malty, round, complete, almost fruity. Great!

A novelty of licorice and great beer, with candi and carmel and brown sugar. Very smooth and a treat to the palate. Brownish colour. Aggressive carbonation Unique and worth trying, but a sweet novelty nevertheless. Thanks Mr. Madsberg, deliverey from Denmark.

Thanks Lachesis for this bottle (Vintage 2004). Hazy dark brown beer with very big beige foam. Intens sweet aroma, sweet nuts, Porto, sweet fruits, cake, banana, roasted malts and yeasty pancakes. Taste is smooth, sweet and fruity. Afthertaste is soft and very complex and has soft burned touches in the finale. A sweet -malty beer with a great balance.

Huge Thanks to ChristianSA for sharing this at Logans- Pours a dark brown, crimson color. Nice sized light brown head. Aroma is awesome, cherrries, grapes, fresh grass, earthyness to it. Flavor is dark cherries, caramel,  smooth and almost greasy on the palate (in a good way).

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 Amazing, a brew that started only recently, and which is already very good! Clear dark brown color, short but lasting brown head. Aroma of prune, grapes, roasted malt, sugar cane. Very strong and penetrating. Full taste of roasted and caramel malts, bit spicy, sweet, some chocolat. Fruity, malty and sweet. Very nice!
UPDATED: JAN 16, 2007 Rerate:  This is the most distinctive and flavorful beer Ive had in a long time.  A remarkable beer.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 Ahh pannepot(2004), where to start. Fruity with sweet malt tones, outstanding aroma, one of the best. Taste is very similar and imencly full bodied, with fruit salad, good carbonation, only bad points are the molasses can kick in to much and make it too sweet, near perfect. Aging will make this one of the best in the world. RERATE: 2005 bottle, Kulminator. This is such an amazing beer. Its just increadibly fruity, candy sugar, its just one of the best beers in the world.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2006 Bottle at Kulminator. This was just great. aroma: peaches, dark fruits and yeasty. taste: sweet, brown candy sugar, licorice and other spices, fruity. finishes sweet, fruity but not very long. full bodied, average carbonation. nice!!!!

Rerate vintage 2005: lets cellar this one, hoping its sweetness is lessened over  time! 7-5-7-4-18

2005 vintage; thanks to Per - pours a dark cloudy brown colour under a rocky creamy and slightly brown-tainted head; deep and incredibly complex aroma where the biscuity maltiness meets notes of orange peel, ginger, molasses and a touch of alcohol; very sweet and full-bodied; high carbonated with a moderate bitterness; oily and voluptous on the tongue; very long cookie maltiness in the finish, accompanied by more spicy and fruity (dates, figs) notes - this is absolutely marvelous !

Bottled. Dark brown opaque colour, huge foamy/creamy brownhead. Very complex aroma, malts, almond, nuts, alcohol, sweet fruit and caramel. Flavour of almond, nuts, sweet alcohol, raisins, plum and caramel. Aftertaste is plummy with strong sweetness. Absolutely lovely palate. Wonderful brew, which excellently hides its ABV. Smooth and soft yet very complex! Thanks omhper!

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 Dark brown coloured, beautiful lasting head. Fantastic aroma, malts, fruit, nuts, some alcohol, bit vinous. Very smooth complex flavour, chocolate, raisins and who knows what else. Fantastic soft mouthfeel. In the category of Rochefort and Westvleteren. Really, really good.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2007 Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells of plums, figs, raisins, oatmeal, brown sugar and some other fruits I couldnt distinguish from one another.  Tastes of grapes, apples, cherries, spices.  Full mouthfeel and a sweet finish.  Good, but a bit overdone.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2007 This was a beer I had trouble keeping in a glass.  Pours dark brown and hazy with a frothy tan head that wouldnt quit.  Aroma was earthy and brown sugar sweet,   Flavor was over the top sweet with some sourness mixed in.  I believe down the road this will be a slightly sour beer as it  ages.  Sweet was all there is on the finish,  Thx Per for the taste of this one.

The aroma is earthy and slightly spicy. Body is hefty but not overly so, well-distributed yeast. This has some spicy (cinnamon) elements to it, but other than that is is fatiguingly sweet. Thanks to JCW for sharing!
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 Very dark colored, frothy head. 2005 vintage. Complex aroma: plums, pepper, nutmeg, maple syrup. Very sweet, sugary flavor with nutmeg, plums, apple, pear, cinnamon, chocolate and raisin. Lovely long aftertaste of apple dumplings. The alcohol is there, but fairly well hidden. I like this beer, but I prefer more body and less sugary sweetness, but the complexity is there. Perhaps this beer will further improve with cellaring.

2007 vintage, tasted in december 2012. Bottle. Marky dark brown color carmel and porto in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with caramel, red fruit and an upcoming tartness. Complex. Majestically matured.

2005 bottle, thanks to Sahlholdt for a great trade.  VERY tall & big dense, foamy, cramy tan head that is rockier at the top.  body is the darkest brown youd ever seen, but not black!  the edges are cloudy and lighter brownish gold.  aroma is tart & tangy, malty sweet like raspberries or sour cherries.  very sweet malty flavor, like very ripe black cherries.  medium carbonation.  yes, sweet gingerbread flavor, some melted brown sugar in there too.  thanks, Jannik!

33cl. bottle 2005 thanks to Mullman for sharing. Pours a dark, murky brown color with a huge tan head. Sweet malty aroma with lots of dark fruits, sweet spices(nutmeg, ginger, cinnamon)
and molasses. Flavor is again very sweet. Malt, brown sugar, raisin bread and a mild alcoholic finish. A bit sweet for me, but excellent nonetheless.

Beer with the most beautiful foam iv ever seen. Color of the beer is warm
brownish with a red reflection in it. The smell is unbelivable, it is sweet,
spicy, Port like, Marsalla too, chocolaty and has touches of burned coffee
beans and nuts. The taste is complex sweet and has an elegant fruityness on
the pallet.It is very desert like, sweet spicy cakes, Irish Coffee, Belgian
Chocolate and raisin bread. This is what ia call refined sweet flavour. The
foam stays on the beer tell the end. Alcohol is very well hidden, and the
afthertaste is much more powerfull than the Westvleteren 12 and the
Rochefort 10 together. This is a real winner.

This was one hell of a surprise at my door!!!! Thanks again, Mike -  eyedrinkale! 

Rating #810
 Vintage 2004 -- This was one bastard of a pour it took nearly 30min because it was all khaki froth. Once the beer settled, the body sits as a dark walnut almost black hue. The head is resilient and laces every millimeter of glass. This is going to be a rather difficult beer to describe. Ive never encountered aromas and flavors as distinctly unique as these. Suggestions of fruit cake, Raisin Bran and green apple are bold and upfront. Something here, probably the dusty cobwebby green apple presence, reminds me of one of my favorite beers of all time: Beatrix. Boldly abstract malty notes of smoky Canadian maple syrup, molasses, fig and date sugars are straight out of the gate. Spicy milled black pepper and a piquant maduro cigar likeness tons of bold flavors chocolate, cedar wood, pumpernickel bread, clove, anis, leather horse saddle, old burlap, sweetened coffee, tangerine, chocolate mousse but spicy?????? 
 The palate is substantially sticky chewy and sweet. The finish is mildly dry and again reminding me of molasses and toasted pumpernickel bread. This is such an odd yet elegant beer extremely Trappist Ale like with the yeast. Rather astonishing, IMO!

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2012 15 Jun 2005 - (Schruers terrace, Margraten) - Old Fishermans Ale - Lovely luscious sweet fruit malt aroma.  Cloudy brown-red, good brown head and reasonable lacing.  Smokey sweet fruit beer, this is different to other beers.  Tangy complex sweet lingering finish.  A big surprise of stone fruit.  Overall - This is a beer that is distinctive.
Brown strong Belgian with large top. Mineral, slightly hoppy / fruity, berry like aroma .Add spice. Brown sugar sweetens life with light bitters, around alcohol. To sweet in order to fully enjoy.

2005 bottle. I hate when beers explode out of the bottle and go to waste in the sink. Especially when its a beer this fine. I really enjoy the perfect aroma with lots of ripe fruit and malts. The flavor is amazing as well but palate is a bit on the sticky side..

Dark, clear garnet with a thin, tightly packed off-white head.  Caramel, licorice, molasses, raisins, oily nuts, lightly toasted bread, coriander, port wine and some mild alcohol.  An incredible, supple, smooth body with perfect carbonation.  The flavors are good, lots of malt and some spice, with the alcohol taking no effect whatsoever, except perhaps, adding a little warmth.  Probably a little sweet, but time will dry that out some, making a truly superb beer world-class.  The finish is long, smooth and clean.  Carlo, I cant wait until this makes it to the US, but until then, thanks for this bottle!

Bitter piney aroma, combined with an elderberry-like component, muddy brown, creamy tan head. Distinctive flavour with the malt and elderberry. Pleasant mouthfeel. Most unusual for the style.

 Thank You so much Unstrup!
Bottle at RBESG Grand Tasting 05. Dark brown, big head. Sweet blended smell, nice. Complex - tobacco, cake mixture, berry, sweet, savoury. Superb blended sweetness.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 Bottle (re-rate): A wonderful beer. Lots of spiceyness, chocolate, caramel, dark fruit, cassis. Mouthfeel is smooth, rich, and well balanced. Warming, but not noticable alcohol in the finish. Almost the perfect dark Belgian strong ale for me, tasty.

(Bottled, 2004 vintage, BBE 07/2007) Very dark brown color with a huge, foamy, lasting, beige head. Big aroma of sweet malt, dried fruit, lots of hops, anise. Very intensely sweet, fruity and malty, chocolatey, barley-port-wineous flavor with a roasty, almost burned, dryish-ashy and bitter finish. Sweetness is a bit less pronounced with the yeast poured in - but still, together with the full body, hides the high ABV completely. Very full-bodied, syrupy-sugary, smooth palate with soft carbonation. Pannepot is like scotch ale, barley wine, trappist, dry stout and sweet port wine, all poured into one. Like tbone_ said, has huge aging potential, but at this age, its way too sweet. Still, when rating a beer this huge and complex, one just cant settle for a score less than 4. Cant wait to get hold of a 3-year-old bottle... These are the beers you keep on rating for.
One of the most complex beers Ive ever had. Just so much happening in your mouth when drinking it.

RBSG 05.  Pours a yeasty chunky and murky brown with a nice tight light beige head.  Aroma is moslty sweet with lots of caramel and toasted malts, and then there is a bunch of belgian yeasty flavors and candi sugar sweetness.  Lots of fruit in the flavor like plum and raisin.  Very malty all the way through with lots of taosted malts, chocolate, and munich like flavors.  Smooth finish and mouthfeel.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2005 Murky brown w/ frothy pale tan foam. Aroma is sweet & yeasty (candy) w/ a chocolaty richness & fruity goodness--a rich melange of milk chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, raisins, figs, brandy, pineapple, dates & cream. Soft, lively, silky feel. Flavour is rich & complex--sweet & fruity w/ a slight brandy-ish edge. Pannepot is my "Beer of the Summer Gathering 05."  It was brilliant. I also had the added pleasure of coming to this beer with absolutely no expectations. It had managed elude my attention. What a treat.

hazy brown, beige head.  fruity, yeasty, very complex aroma with notes of chocolate and fruitcake, nuts, toffee and a hint of ginger.  flavours hold mostly dark malkt and chocolate with some maple and boozy port notes.  not as complex as the aroma and very very sweet.  a good beer, right now could be drunk on its own for dessert, with age I think it would tunr to the classic everyone thinks it is now.

Bottle.  Cloudy brown in colour, tan coloured head, lingering lace.  Aroma of gingerbread, caramel, chocolate, toffee, dark fruits.  The flavour was slighty yeasty, some spices, chocolate fruit cake, slightly sweet.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium body, medium-high carbonation, no noticable alcohol.  Finishes with a lingering bitterness, some warmth.  Truly phenomenal stuff.

Bottled 33cl (BB 07/2007)
Almost opaque black, big foamy tanned head. Rye-bread, chocolat, berries, hay and roasted malts in the nose. Full-bodied. Sweet, tickling carbonation. Chocolate, candy sugar, metal notes. Huge ageing potential but didnt impress me. Dont believe the hype.

RBSG 05 - talk about a beer living up to my expectations of it, this stuff was fantastic.  a chocolate brown color, cloudy and topped with a cream colored head. aroma full with sweet malts, yeast, chocolate, and spices. flavors stacked with spices, ginger, maple sugar, caramel malts, yeast and a little bit of hops.  body was thick and viscous, easily coating the sides of the glass.  from first sip to the last, this beer was packed with unbelievable flavors, was incredibly smooth with zero abv showing up.  its no surprise to me how quickly this beer has ascended our ranks.

Muddy brown in color, tan head. Fantastic combination of fruit, cake, fruitcake, gingerbread, and chocolate. This is a full round of desserts in a single glass. Rediculously easy to drink, no signs of the alcohol, creamy body slides down the gullet. Man this stuff is good.

[bottle at RBSG]
Hazy, dark reddish-brown with a bubbly, yellow-tan cover.  Barleywinish aroma of sweet cereal grains/ pumpernickel with sour banana notes.  The taste is as expected from the aroma and more: sweet, biscuity pumpernickel with a significant amount of hops flavour, yet no bitterness.  Those hops synergize with the sweetness to make some unique, but difficult to identify flavour--maple syrup?  Some chocolate.  Overall, too sweet, though.  Medium to full body with low carbonation and a clean finish.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2005 Special thanks to sk8viking for this tremendous brew!  2004 bottle (I couldnt restrain myself).  Deep brown pour that formed a huge frothy tan head when it hit the glass... head receded to about 1/3" and remained there.  Aroma was exceedingly sweet with caramel, plums, raisins, anise, chocolate... just wonderful!  Flavor was equally sweet and complex.  Very full mouthfeel that coated and teased every tastebud.  Flavors followed the aroma, with the addition of some spices (similar to coriander) and a bit of hop presence.  Alcohol was not really apparent until it warmed the throat on the sweet malty finish.  Magnifique!

Bottle sampled @ RBSG 05 (Montréal) Grand TastingDark auburn, thick tan head, tons of lacing. Nose of sweet caramel; no, beyond caramel, almost like carrot cake with a touch of fragrant hops. This is so good. Im having a hard time putting the glass down to write, I dont know how to commit this to paper. MartinT has a good rating, go read his, Im going to enjoy this.

Murky brown pour with a short tan head. Chocolate cake and icing sugar aroma. Citrus, coffee, chocolate and toffee resonate throughout. Its like being in a universe full of sugar that totally clouds the palate. Certainly well made but needs to sit. Kasteelbier Donker memories are abound in this beer. Lots of booze. Too strong.. Too sweet for the moment. Lots of potential but non quite ready.

2005 RBSG - thanks to Jens.  Well, is this beer realy worth all the hype?  YOU BET.  Smooth, chocolatey - malty - delicious.  Raisin, dark roasted malt, luxurious.  This beer is very tasty.  Well worth the hype.

(bottle in Kulminator, Antwerp).  Amazing beer - as thick as treacle with a milk-stout character.  Lots of liquorice, aniseed, sweet malt and caramel but still balanced with a roasty dryness.  The huge alcohol is well hidden but makes the finish a massive explosion of flavour.  Complex, rich, thick and massive beer with more character than is good for it.

bottle. thanks Jens! muddy brownish-mahogany coloured body with a fluffy off-white head and specks of yeast sediment. aroma is pleasing and provides almost a pleasure overload - notes of plum, chocolate, and faint alcohol. the body is huge! fruit notes, malty, sugary sweet, and light alcohol... completely married to produce a phenomenally complex Belgian Strong. Very much enjoyed.

RBSG
Thanks to Jens for filling his magic suitcase with exotic brews from afar. A RB European gathering would be a pleasure to attend!
This one starts with a murky dark brown pour that fills the rest of the glass with a big frothy off white head.
Light malt aroma that is backed up by a moderate sweetness on the tongue. 
The alcohol is well hidden in this brew, but a bit more complexity would be nice.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 July 2007. 2006 Vintage bottle shared by DuctTape. Very dark brown body with a small foamy brown head. Fruity aroma almost like cherries with hints of brandy, sweet malt. Sweet rich malt in the flavour has a fruitiness similar to the aroma. Dry fruity finish has a light bitterness to it that contrasts with the sweetness of the malt. Medium bodied palate suits the beer. Very nice but gets a bit heavy as the glass goes on. 7-8/4/7-8/4/16-17 - 3.9 (Could go to 4.0 or 4/1 if I were more in the mood for it)

July 2005. RBSG. Presumably 2005 vintage? Dark brown with a small fluffy beige head. Gorgeous lacing on the glass. Sweet malt and sugar in the aroma is a touch muted. Very sweet, delicately malty beer. Quite smooth, medium bodied mouthfeel. Quite nice. 7/4/8/4/16 - 3.9

Pour was caramel color with almost no head...smell is chocolate, yeast, horseblanket, then alcohol and dark fruits...taste was sweet and caramel with strong chocolate and yeast...delicious sweet finish...

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2008 2005 vintage bottle sampled on 3/28/08: Aroma has some big light fruity notes and even a touch of acidity and sweet dark Belgian caramel.  Body starts sweet and sugary with some fruity esters and light oxidation.  Not sure if its this vintage or the age, but this is pretty one-dimensional and not as complex as I remember.

2006 vintage bottle sampled on 3/12/07: Has some more body and sweetness with a touch of smoke and bigger dark fruitiness than I remember in previous vintages.  Exhibits nice balance and complexity.

Sampled at the RBSG 05 bottle tasting courtesy of Ungstrup: Pours a muddy dark brown with a puffy, but somewhat short-lived, light tan head with clumpy lacing.  Aroma is rich, chocolatey and earthy with a touch of gingerbread.  Body starts rich, caramely and sticky sweet with lots of milk chocolate caramel, some lactose, and mild dark fruitiness.  Nice subtle Belgian yeastiness balances this unique and very complex beer.  I love the thick, bready chocolate sweetness, but this would be very nice if aged for a few years as well.  Thanks Jens!

This was one of the surprise hits for me at the RBSG.  Jens really hooked a brother up with this one.  Vintage 2005.  Murky brown beer with a foamy brown head.  Very lively on the tongue.  The nose was sweet and fruity, reminding me of blueberry and maple syrup.  This is a sweet beer, with lots of berry sweetness (blueberry, black raspberry), ripe plums, and caramel sweetness.  This was a surprisingly light, aromatic beer for the ABV.  Simply delightful.
RBSG 2005: Poured dark brown with a massive beige head. Whiskey aroma and alcohol. Flavor is massively sweet with light caramel and dark fruit notes. Thanks Jens.

(330ml bottle, RBSG05) Big tan head topped by opaque brown body.  Aroma is medium sweet, yeast, raisin, cocoa.  Taste is sweet, milk chocolate, light anise.  Creamy full body that renders the alcohol virtually invisible.

RBSG 05 Pours a murky brown color with a beige head that leaves nice lacing on the glass. Amazing aroma of plums, yeast, liquorice and malt. Amazing flavor of plums, malt, yeast and liquorice, its sweet but not cloying. Light to medium body. liquorous texture, moderate carbonation. Thanks Jens !

(33cl bottle) Sampled at RBSG 2005 in Montreal. Thanks to Jens for the Top50 sample! Pours a deep brown body with a yellowish, frothy head. The nose is of figs, tar, seed. Flavour is awfully sweet and smooth. 10% abv is hidden nicely by the red licorice sweetness but I do not see the complexity others claim?

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Fresh bottle: Dark brown body, like a dark dubbel or schwartzbier... good maple coloring at the edge of the glass and some deep burgundy plum colors elsewhere. Has a huge tan head up top.  Nose is full of oak, sweet spiced dark fruits such as plums, dates, maybe some burnt apricots... amazingly complex beer.  Flavor is centered around some peppery, spicy active yeast with dark plums and black cherries at times... sweet belgian yeast and a molasses character in the finsh.


Rerate 2006 bottle had in 2008.  I just dont think I like the sweetness and sugary candy thing going on in this beer anymore.  Every time I try it I like it less and less and I crave a true Westvleteren, Rochefort or St Bernardus more and more.  I guess this is why my ratings of the Reserva and Grand Reserva are below average.  Im to the point where I like Pannepøt more than Pannepot.  Score lowered from 4.3 to 3.7.


Rerate from 5-year old bottle shared by Urbain at Struise Farm (first batch): WOW.  4.4.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2009 RBSG05 bottle thanks to Jens.  Mild, sourish aroma with mild vinous and sweet notes.  The aroma seems to be off and is very slight.  Hazy brown/amber color with a large tan head.  Fruity, vinous cherry flavor with sweet chocolates following to start.  Hints of brown sugars as well.  This is very tasty.  Smooth and quite drinkable.  I wish the aroma were a little more assertive.  The flavor and drinkability of this makes up for the lack of aroma, though(5/4/9/5/17).---- ounce bottle purchased from the Davis Food Co-Op.  2007 vintage.  Aroma has a nice, sweet, chocolatey smell.  There are some light esters present with a bit of peatiness and some leather.  Pleasant.  Ruddy-dark amber body that is moderately opaque, along with a medium tan head that is pretty strong.  Starts a bit spicy with some tingly carbonation.  Becomes sweet with some chocolate notes and some roasted coffee.  Notes of dried, pitted fruits also make a strong presence as well as some tobacco roastiness later.  Warming, but not overly ethanolic.  Good nuttiness in the afterfinish.  Damn fine.

2005 RBSG Montreal Friday Night Tasting. Murky brown colour with a frothy tan head. Raisin, molasses, brown sugar, light citrus, faint alcohol and grapefruit aroma. Very sweet, with brown sugar, light alcohol, molasses, light citrus, raisin, and faint licorice. Full bodied, rich, and warming.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 2005 bottle...RBSG 2005... This beer rocks!... Murky, mahogany ale with a large, frothy, tan head. Great retention. Milk chocolate, red wine, ginger and hazelnut nose. Malty, alcoholic flavor with notes of coriander, toasted nuts, port, buttermilk, dates and vanilla. Full-bodied and velvety with soft carbonation.  The finish is lengthy and definitely a touch sweet for me, but this is a forgivable distraction within an otherwise wonderful beer. Terrific!
Full sweet malt aroma with fruit and flowers. Clear brown colour with great head and lacing. Sweet malt flavour with stone fruit. Smooth palate.

330 ml bottle from 2004 shared with too many at the Ratebeer Mondial gathering.  This get-together will mostly be remembered I think for the vast numbers of bodies squeezed into Stephens small apartment, the struggle of the A/C to compensate, and Sprocket loving the Vervifontaine but nothing else.  The beers, for the most part, were not spectacular or if they were, had been tried by most of the participants.  New masterpieces?  Just this.  Chocolaty-root beer nearly opaque color with a ring of lasting foam...immensely rich chocolate-hazelnut-caramel sweet nose, so decadent that you just want to fill a towel with it and sit in a steam room all day...light spiciness keeps it from cloying...body is full of molasses sweetness and pungency, brown sugar, chocolate soda...later, anise and vanilla help to give complexity, and bready yeast forms a nice foundation...smooth milky body offers tiny hints of port at the finish...marvellous, though I definitely need a larger sample.

2004 Vintage bottle at Delirium Cafe, Brussels, Belgium  Light brown, creamy head, which diminishes totally.  Deep brown bodied.  Stoutie aroma: heavy malts of coekies, toasted, caramel.  Moderately sweet, lightly bitter, somewhat spicy initial flavour.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter (long) finish.  Fully bodied.  This beer can be situated between a Rochefort 10 and a Westy 12.  It has some spiciness as the Westy and has the malts of Rochefort 10.  The Struise Brouwers have a recipe for a classic beer as Oerbier, Orval, ...

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2011 Bottle (2010 bottling).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (caramel, chocolate, cookie), with notes of brown sugar, orange peel, date, and alcohol.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.

Full body, syrupy  texture, lively carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.

Well, its big and sweet, just what most RateBeer folks like. The aroma does have some allure, but its difficult to drink.  Sugar, sugar, alcohol, and sugar.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 Foggy brown colour with a big bwige foam. Sweet, vinous aroma of luxury chocolate, cardammon, licorice, port and baked apples. Sweet full flavour of toffee, cardammon, sweet licorice and nougat. Long sweet aftertaste of nougat, black pepper, red grapes and raisin. Wonderfull stuff. Thanks Bierkönig!

Coriander and bitter orange spiciness with dark notes of figs, dates, molasses, chocolate and black tea in the complex and compelling aroma.  Opaque brown body with a low, but lasting cover of fine-bubbled tan head.  Sweet, brown, round and malty with dark pit fruitiness and huge tea-like tannins.  Coriander and bitter orange in the long, drawn-out finish.  Wonderful soft carbonation and thick rich body that caresses the tongue.  Mild alcohol warming.  Thats luxury!  Bottle enjoyed at the Ratebeer Mondial Gathering 2005.

33 cl bottle. Served in Rochefort goblet. Hazy reddish-brown. Head is very large and off-white w/ very good lastability. The aroma is pleasantly, sweetly malty, warmly spicy, darkly fruity, w/ some chocolate, and slight alcohol presence. The flavor is well-structured and harmonic: dark fruit, warm spices, a bit of alcohol, nice sweetness. Fabulous, soft mouthfeel and excellent frinkability. A fantastic beer!

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2005 A gift from lachesis, a man as good at brewing as he is generous. Hell, hes bought me beer, given me beer, driven me to train stations, introduced me to people... I could go on. I wasnt going to rate any beers in Europe but this beer really deserves an extra rating. I drank this in a hostel in Oost-Vleteren after visiting the abbey slightly to the west. Drank it after a Westy Abt and theres no doubt this is the superior beer. Deep brown colour, this bottle had pretty ordinary head retention but other bottles have had an incredible, mountainous head that goes absolutely nowhere. The aroma really makes the beer in this one - theres an incredible range of stuff in which little stands out above the rest; licorice, nutmeg, cardamom, brandied oranges, prunes, currants and even a touch of beechwood smokiness late. Carbonation is high bordering on explosive though I was drinking it after it sat in my bikes saddlebags for about 200km. The major knock on this beer is that its too sweet for my tastes to be perfect. As lachesis recommends, serving it slightly cool helps in this respect, but its hardly a major issue. Intense malt flavour without being caramelly and tasting "dark" without being roasty. Strong sultana fruitiness, no alcohol character at all. The sweetness is more light and worty than the really thick cloying type. Some more hop character and this is a world-classic for mine. Seems like this beer would age incredibly well, and I have a bottle, though how it survives the trip home after the trip on the bike is anyones guess. GREAT WORK CARLO!
Dark red colour. Large thick head. Taste is somewhat powerful and portwine like. Quite sweet with hints of prunes and sweet apples. Very pleasant. Long soft sweet finish.

2004 bottle provided by Rastacouere at the Mondial Ratebeer Tasting, 6/4/2005.  Hazy, drab-olive brown.  Very earthy toned and resembling the Trappist beers exactly.  Initial medium-sized beige head recedes slowly to cover/ring, leaving little lacing.  Raspberries, fresh and juicy, in the aroma, with deep, richly extracted brown malts and a smooth Belgian yeast.  Further sniffing provides more brown sugar, toffee, barley and yeast.  I love it! Very strong aroma.  Sweet toffee and brown sugar-like maltiness to start the flavor, light balancing bitterness and omnipresent yeast.  Just beautiful and artfully done.  Tannins provide light tartness, some brown tea-leaves towards the end and an easygoing, yet full body and mouthfeel.  Low carbonation, no alcohol noted, which is impressive, because I can find it in Westy 12 and Rocheforte 10.  Caramelly malt is decidedly malty, not sugary.  Vanilla essences linger on. . .I think I like this better than Rocheforte 10 and about as much as Westy 12, mabye more.

Ohh......what a great Belgian strong ale. Very caramel, malty sweet with a load of spices. Foam is very creamy and longlastring....a true marvel. Very dense and sweet, spicy and very complex taste. Stout malts give it a roasty taste, and the candi sweeteness in combination with delicious refreshing spices completes this wonderful beer into extraordinary. This is Belgian Beery Heaven folks. Top quality !

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 Couleur brune brouillée, presque pleinement opaque.  Énorme mousse beige plutôt persistante adhérant partiellement à la paroi du verre.  Aromes complexes et multidimensionnelles de dattes, gâteau aux fruit confits, fruits séchés et de sucre à pâtisserie.  Remarquable équilibre en bouche entre le sucre et les levures.  Biscuits au miel, mélasse, gros gâteau riche de malt, quelques composantes phénolique et épicées.  Moussant pleinement en bouche, texture sirupeuse, niveau de carbonatation parfait, aucune trace dalcool du début à la fin.  Un vrai coup de coeur.  Encore svp!

Bière brune avec une lueur rougeâtre et une mousse épaisse, crémeuse et très aromatique et fantastique. arome très complexe d épices douces, du café, du chocolat, du cognac, des fruits en alcool, des malts, des gâteaux foncés, des herbes et du caramel. Le goût est très doux et très bien équilibré. Arome en outre énorme de malts, des fruits secs, du caramel, des épices, des gâteaux, des biscuits et du café noir. Bière fantastique à boire.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2012 Original rating:  Muddy brown colour like chocolate fudge.  Large, dense head.  Voluptuous aroma - figs, milk chocolate, sherry, alcohol, fruitcake, demerara, double devonshire cream...dessert in a glass.  Silky sweet palate - this beer glides effortlessly like Lijiang Yinjiu.  A sensual combination of the softest Belgian chocolate, the sweetest dates, whisky nectar - the lush maltiness of Ardbeg without the phenols.  Pannepot is evocative - the guilty euphoria of a childhood bowl of chocolate chip cookie dough. This is an artists finest hour - a masterpiece.2006 bottle, consumed in 2012.  Dark brown, there was some head early, and its opaque I think with yeast.  The aroma is sweet, sugary malts with light, date and fig dark sugars. Silky sweet, very smooth.  There are some soy sauce notes from oxidation, but a very refined beer with a lot of luscious sweet sugars.  This is very good, although I dont like it as much as a fresh Pannepot.  3-8-9-4-17 =  4.1

Bottle - sampled at the Copenhagen beerfestival 2005
Crimsom brown, fluffy head.
sugar and berry roast aroma.
Complex flavors, I need to try a full bottle :-),  
Fruit sugar, plums, strawberries.
Rich body, sparkly at the end.
Fantastic brew.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2007 2004 bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with a big yellowish head. Date-, prune- and alcohol aroma. Big and stable off-white head. Tastes quite sweet of molasses and sirup spiced with dates, figs and prunes. Hint of burnt caramel. A strong effect in the back of the mouth - nice. Medium to high carbonation. Very full beer with a sweet finish.

2004 bottle. Two thumbs up to Jeppe for introducing me to that piece of cake. Lasting beige foam head covers a musty brown body. Heavy molasses hit you first in the sea of dark fruits (dates, fennel, figs etc.) Very deep malt aroma, no alcohol sensation at all, but a certain rummy feel. Raisins, smoke, abbaye des rocs like powerful esters and coriander/cardamom plus tea tannins. Rich toasty malt still has plenty of residual sugars bathing in an herbal garden. Drying nicely in mouth despite the massive sweetness. A fruit bacchanalia. Toffee, banana, corn, candi sugar and mellow leafy bitterness closes the encounter. Lightest carbonation, medium bodied.. Phenomenal stuff, I definitely prefer this over a rochefort and possible over a westy, unadulterated sweetness glory. Congratulations to Carlo, a very potent top 50 candidate.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2012 The Lure:Cherry-chocolate cake stuffed with figs, laced with toffee and molasses, topped by lavender and rose petals. Utterly engaging and decadent, emboldened by a superb head and its accompanying lacing. Im ready to get my scuba gear and dive in without an oxygen tank.

The Festivities:A dream house entirely made of chocolate mousse, of the eclectic variety of course. Dry nuts were used to erect sturdy walls, ground cocoa and luscious yeast were cemented into a succulent foundation, and toffee bars laid out as shingles. Milky coriander leaves and candied orange peels sparsely cover the walls in just the right quantity. You simply cannot ask for more luxury and comfort.

Transcendence:Pens are flying on paper, a tantalizing fairy tale is being written as we speak.

An aged batch (2-3 years old) presents similar complexities to fresher batches, still in a rich, velvety, smooth mouthfeel. These Struise guys have created a bona fide gem.

A tap version of the 2008 vintage at Ma Che Siete Venuti a Fà was even more engaging yet less spicy than the bottles I am used to. The roastier and fruitier (vinous, black cherries) profile was mindblowing. This was already a masterpiece, but if they can bottle this same experience, it is going to be legendary in my book.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2005 (on bottle - 2004 edit.)Perfect ale, for sure. I don´t know what to say; witch tells alot about how easy it is to fry a beer, but when you get a perfect specimen, you´re left speachless.......Figs, dades, sunflower, raisins, canesugar; ther´re all there and they are so in sync. , i´ll be looking forward to what ageing does, ´cause this brews starts where all the others(including westy 12)ends.
