Has a dadecolour and small beige head. the finish turns fruity on you and blows millions of apples/pears/abricots and smoothnes at you, you´re lips tremble in fevercramp. Where to go after drinking the Gods own nectar?(You can just put the money in the usual acount, Jeppe).

Bottled. Cloudy red-brown colour with a huge beige head.
Acidic aroma with lots of dried fruit, wood, spices, tobacco and chocolate.
Very complex sweet flavour, with lots of dried fruits, tobacco and chocolate.
Reminds me a bit of Rochefort 10, but this one is sweeter and much better.
Thanks Jeppe for getting this beer to Denmark and thanks lachesis for brewing this great beer.
Definately one of my favorite beers.

Thanks to Lachesis for this beauty! Aged for 6 months. Had this as my first beer to celebrate my graduation from college.  I started her out with a gentle pour and a HUGE head formed. No need to go with a vigerous pour on this one. Poured dark brown with a HUGE off white head. The head had what I call lasting power as I had to wait forever until it was at a drinkable level. Left lacing all the way down and was heavily carbonated. The aroma was apricot, pear, and white grapes, as well as slighly sour and moderately sweet. At first I noticed a chocolate malt to the flavor. The beer started moderately sweet, but became more sweet with every sip. Some fruit flavors (cherry?) and caramel too. The palate was amongst the best I have ever had. It was like the tongue was being massaged by silk. Velvety silk smooth, simply glorious. In the middle of drinking this one I even yelled out, "This is exquisite!" and it was my first beer of the day, so it wasnt the alcohol talking. Had a lingering sweet finish too it. The palate was beyond impressive.

Bottle. Big and inviting aroma. Fantastic appearance with the most beatiful off-white head. Flavor is amazing, big touch of liquorice but also different fruits, especially prunes. Perfect smooth mouthfeel with very long finish. Overall this a BIG ale, a must-taste for anybody whos into Belgian Ales

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2005 Bottle. Sweet dried fruit aroma. Dark chestnut colour. Stable light brown head. Sweet flavour, distinct liquorice notes. Quite high carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. Thanks to Lachesis for this one.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Bottle, thanx to Lachesis for this great beer. Dark red brown colour with a huge baige head. Sweet spicy fruity vanilla aroma and a sweet fruity taste, no trace of the 10%. Medium to full body and a sweet finish.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2007 Rerated vintage 2005
Almost blackwith big lasting head.
The aroma fills my nose just pouring it in the glass. Complex aroma with some notes of dried fruits and dark sugar. very good, can wait to wait to taste it.
very BIG and complex taste with a full body. malty,dark sugar, yeast in the good way and a lingering aftertaste of dried fruits and notes of burnt sugar, again in the good way. Great beer

Vintage 2004 - lots of thanks to lachesis for this wonderful treat- that was a great present. Huge light brown, frothy and sticky head. Murky brown colored brew with hints of orange. An intense yeast nose with medium sweet apricot intervalls, also some earthy and bark tones. Intense vanilla, dough and candy taste with a slightly bitter kick in the middle, but very short. Sweetness overlaps mostly. There are hints of pine in the finish followed by an intense almond and alcohol (like amaretto) accomplished with an sweet apricot taste. Smooth and round, a bit too sweet. I*m very curious how it will age - another bottle is stored for a later rerate.

Perfumy nose with a little chocolate, yeast and alcohol. Dark brown color with a huge spongy biege head that was sticky. Candy-sweet malt - like a cough drop. Dark fruit tastes - figs, raisins - and a little toffee flavor. Toasted malt end. Thick body. Leaves a very thick deposit of sweet malt on the lips like a lollipop. Think body. Alcohol is quite present, particularly after the swallow, and it intensifies everything. A good dessert beer - very interesting.  Only complaint might be that its too sweet.

Kulminator. Described as a sweet stout(type). It was very sweet and complex, but the roasted tones at the end were very limited and only slightly noticeable. Still this is a very impressive brew, very Abtlike (including the alcohol) with the notes of raisins, prunes, caramel and pure sugar.

Bottled: Reddish colour. Clear. Highly carbonated. Fluffy dark beige head. Malt, light liqourice, fruit and spices in the aroma. Flavour of vanilla, liqourice, sweetness and fruit. Is quite full bodied. Is sweet and spicy in the end. Has a good balanced alcoholwarmth on lips and palate. Very nice one.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with large, pillowy, long lasting, off-white head. Nice lace too. Wonderful aroma; sweet, plum, fig, wine. Full bodied, liquid candy flavor, finishes slightly dry and figgy. Just lovely! A sure winner with deserts or as a night cap.

Bottled. Mahogany colour, rich head. Aroma of red berries. Sweet, lightly roasty and rather vinous. Richly malty with velvetty soft mouthfeel. Powerful, yet balanced. A full bodied, intensely aromatic world class beer.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2005 Lovely sweetish aroma, dark fruits, prunes, some spices, apples, sweets and alcohol. This one pours, or should we say gushes, hazy dark brown to burgundy, with a frothy medium off-white head, but it doesnt last long.  Good malt sweetness in the flavor, fruity, apples and oranges, some spice too. The alchol is well pronounced but not too much. Good carbonation. IMO a fantastic brew, great to see that BierKönig as the only in Denmark has it in his shop.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Hazy warm brown colored beer with thick creamy frothy head. Aromas of gingerbread, caramel, coffee, liquorice and almondcakes. The taste is sweet and complex due to spices, wood, caramel, coffee and peppercake ending in a fruity light alcoholic taste. I had the chance to drink this beer on draught at the Poperinges Karakterbier festival and I must say that a rerate was necessary. Simply amazing how the guys from Struise keep on the great brew work with such an amazing level of quality. Thx a lot.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2005 Brown almost black beer with huge creamy frothy puffy head that lasts very long. The nose is very complex with sweet malts, peppercake and liquorice giving a fantastic flavor that is very sweet and soft. For a 10% abv the alcohol & carbonation is fantasticly well balanced. The aftertaste keeps on giving the necessary sweetness.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2006 Bottled, drank it at kulminator Antwerp. Dark brown beer with dens creamy head. The aroma is sweet with mild spices, brown sugar, and dark brown chocolate. The taste lets me think of mild spice, brown sugar, liquorice, roasted malts, ripened fruits and raisins. Well balanced carbonation and light alcohol warming. The aftertaste gives me more  spices, liquorice and sweetened maltsand some chocolate as well. Very complex for a dark ale.

Heavily spiced, mouth-watering brew from... whats that name again? Never heard of them, but this is a fine strong ale by any standard. Fairly lively carbonation, but this does nothing to ruin this thick, brown surprise from... Caulier -- dont forget the name, its worth memorizing.

Intens brown beer with a reddish glow and a fantastic thick, creamy and very aromatic foam. You can smell this beer from a distance. very complex aroma of sweet spices, coffee, chacolate, cognac, fruits in alcohol, malts, dark cakes, herbs and buther-caramel. Taste is very sweet and very well balanced. Also HUGE aromas of malts, dry fruits, caramel, spices, cakes, cookies and black coffee. I was told to drink it from the fridge. Huge beer with loads of finesse.
Hazy reddish brown colour with big off white head. Malty aroma, lots of dark fruit and yeast. Flavor is sweet with fruit and spices, hints of alcohol in the finish.

Bottle. Murky brown beer with huge puffy head with excellent retention. The nose is something special with sweet malt, dark fruit and redwine leading to a complex, fruity, vineous flavor with alcohol, dried fruit and sugary sweetness. Carbonation is good for style and mouthfeel is huge and almost sirupy. As the beer warms the sweetness may become a bit cloying on its own, making it the perfect companion for desserts. A grand beer, on par with some of the trappist brews.
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2005 A deep red beer with a huge brown head. The aroma is sweet spicy with notes of ginger and caramel. The flavor is very sweet and again with notes of spices and caramel.

Bottle conditioned, Kulminator Antwerpen. Pleasantly sweet nose with some fruitiness and a roasted edge. Over sweet in the mouth with hints of fruity wort and berries. Slightly cloying in the finish with some sweet fruitiness.
Dark with a small head. Very fruity aroma. Sweet fruity taste. Rather simple.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2005 This is the best beer so far. Strange hazy warm brown color with thick creamy froth. powerfull sweet nose with touche of gingerbread, caramel, coffee, speculoos, and almondcakes. The taste is on the sweet side and has a complex mix of spices, tropical wood (cigare box) caramel, coffee and x-mas pudding. In the aftertaste also touches dried fruits. Newyear gift from my kids.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2006 Pours hazy dark brown with some yeast sediment and a foamy tan head. Both aroma and flavor is very full with plenty of malt, spices, prunes, raisins, yeast and dark fruit. Very soft and smooth with a long lasting finish. Quite sweet but the spices makes a really nice balance. A very nice Belgium ale in the same league as a lot of the Trappist beers! Big thanks to the great brewer Carlo (lachesis) for sending me this liquid delicacy.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2007 HUGE thanks to lachesis for this beer! Dark brown with ruby around the edges. Medium, dense fluffy tan head. Aroma is sweet with mild spices, custard, brown sugar, and dark chocolate. Perhaps even angel food cake. Taste is heavenly! Mild spice, more custard, brown sugar, light roasted malts, liquor, dark ripened fruits and cocoa. Body is thick and rich with strong carbonation and light alcohol warming. Finishes with more light spices, liquor, sweetened malts, rich custard, and sucrose. Light bittersweet chocolate as well. Awesome beer! This was the rating for batch two. Again, huge thanks go out to Carlo (lachesis)!

Bottle at the t Brugs Beertje pub in Brugge, Belgium. Appearance was carbonation and opaque with a dark brown hue. Aroma was malty, caramel, and alcohol. Flavor was malty and sweet. Mouthfeel was tingly along with a burning sensation. Fair lacing.
Murky brown color with hardly a lasting head. Aroma is a nice maltiness with some dried fruits. The taste is a bit strong of alcohol and vineous. Sweet caramel and figs follwed by dark roasted malts.

The DM & Hotstuffs European Honeymoon trip beer number 34. This bottled brew from the t Brugs Beertje pub in Brugge poured a small head of white colored fine to medium sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a transparent yet semi cloudy orange brown colored body and a good lacing.  The aroma was malty with a strong vinous note and the mouth feel was tingly and bubbly from start to finish.  It had a nice malt hop dough sweet bread flavor.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 Poured a cloudy brown color with a large off white head and no lacing.  Aroma of mint, dark fruits, roast, yeast, and a funky barnyard aspect as well.  Taste was sweet raisins, chocolate, roast, tons of spices and an alcohol burn.  Too much spice in this one.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2006 Hazy dark brown, nearly black; dirty yellow head. Rich, malty, portwine-like and chocolate/toffee nose, sweet but rich. Touch of tobacco and spices. Sweet taste; flavour of both sweet and bitter chocolates, a bit piney and resinous. Little hops. Marssala or portwine finish. Rich, velvety MF, full-bodied. Nice beer. I have a distinct impression this is less spiced than the Rochefortoise dark, and hence much sweeter in appearance.

 Pannepot 2006, Deca 
Colour: Huge yellow-brown head, near black beer. 4/5.
Nose: My co-taster says Coca-Cola, I get hazelnut, sweet, light  drop  and licorice, as well as some more herbs. We agree the beer has reminiscences of the early version of t Kappitel Watou, dubbed "Bierchampagne". 7/10
Taste: Caramelized apples, quite sweet-fruity, and alcohol; and indeed some cola. As well as a bit of tobacco + black cardemom. 7/10
Palate: Alcohol obvious, very well-bodied, sticky from yet unfermented sugars (beer is very young) 5/5
Overall: Well, this is really pretty good, but it promises heaven. Just give this 2-3 years to ripe and it is seventh heaven indeed. 18/20
